revision.text:
[[File:Anne McDonald Centre.jpg|thumb|316x316px|The Anne McDonald Centre in Melbourne for disabled people with little or no communication skills.]] {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2013}} {{Use Australian English|date=October 2013}} '''Anne McDonald''' (11 January 1961 – 22 October 2010) was an [[Australia]]n person with [[cerebral palsy]] who has been credited as an author and an activist for the rights of people with communication disability. McDonald was born on 11 January 1961 in Seymour, Victoria, a small Australian town. As a result of a birth injury, she developed severe athetoid cerebral palsy. Because she could not walk, talk or feed herself, she was diagnosed as having severe [[intellectual disability]]. At the age of three, she was placed by her parents in St. Nicholas Hospital, [[Melbourne]], a Health Commission (government) institution for children with severe disabilities, and she lived there without education or therapy for eleven years. It has been claimed that, during McDonald's time in the hospital, she was neglected and starved and at age 16 she weighed only 12 kilograms.Rosemary Crossley, "Speechless: Facilitating Communication for People Without Voices", Dutton Adult (1997), {{ISBN|0-525-94156-8}} Despite her ill-treatment, McDonald was purported to have considered herself "a lucky one" in that she was able to be released, and to have estimated that 163 of her friends died in the institution while she was there.Carman, Gerry [http://www.smh.com.au/national/obituaries/persistence-and-passion-speak-loudest-20101031-178v0.html "Persistence and passion speak loudest" (obituary)]. ''The Sydney Morning Herald'', 1 November 2010 In 1977, when McDonald was 16, [[Rosemary Crossley]] reported that she was able to communicate with her by supporting her upper arm while she selected word blocks and magnetic letters. Crossley continued using similar strategies with McDonald and other individuals with disabilities, developing what has become known as [[facilitated communication]] training. Scientific studies have since demonstrated that facilitated communication is not actually effective, and that the resulting messages are essentially written by the facilitators themselves, often unconsciously.{{Cite journal|last=Green |first=Gina |date=1994 |title=Facilitated communication: Mental miracle or sleight of hand? |url=http://www.skeptic.com/02.3.green-fc.html |journal=Skeptic |volume=2 |pages=68-76 |via= |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20021217224216/http://www.skeptic.com/02.3.green-fc.html |archivedate=17 December 2002 }}{{cite web|url=https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2015/02/150226154644.htm|title=Why debunked autism treatment fads persist|website=Science Daily|publisher=Emory University|display-authors=etal|last1=Lilienfeld|accessdate=10 November 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://dailyorange.com/2016/04/syracuse-universitys-reinforcement-of-facilitated-communication-inexcusable-concerning/|title=Syracuse University's reinforcement of facilitated communication inexcusable, concerning|first=|date=|website=The Daily Orange|publisher=Syracuse University|last1=Editorial Board|accessdate=13 April 2016}}{{cite journal|date=13 July 2012|title=The moral obligation to be empirical: Comments on Boynton's 'Facilitated Communication - what harm it can do: Confessions of a former facilitator'|url=http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/17489539.2012.704738|journal=Evidence-Based Communication Assessment and Intervention|publisher=Taylor & Francis Group|volume=6|issue=1|pages=36–57|doi=10.1080/17489539.2012.704738|via=|last1=Todd|first1=James T.|accessdate=March 18, 2015}}{{Cite journal|last=Hall|first=Genae A.|date=1993|title=Facilitator Control as Automatic Behavior: A Verbal Behavior Analysis|url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2748555/pdf/anverbbehav00034-0091.pdf|journal=The Analysis of Verbal Behavior|volume=11|pages=89–97|via=|doi=10.1007/bf03392890|pmc=2748555|pmid=22477083}}{{cite journal|last2=Mulick|first2=James A.|last3=Schwartz|first3=Allen A.|date=September 1995|title=A History of Facilitated Communication: Science, Pseudoscience, and Antiscience: Science Working Group on Facilitated Communication|journal=American Psychologist|publisher=American Psychological Association,Inc.|volume=50|issue=9|pages=750–765|doi=10.1037/0003-066x.50.9.750|last1=Jacobson|first1=John W.}}[http://www.apa.org/research/action/facilitated.aspx ''Facilitated Communication: Sifting the Psychological Wheat from the Chaff''.] American Psychological Association. June 13, 2016. Through Crossley, McDonald appeared to seek discharge from St. Nicholas. Her parents and the hospital authorities denied her request on the grounds that the reality of her communication had not been established. In 1979, when McDonald turned eighteen, she commenced a [[habeas corpus]] action in the [[Supreme Court of Victoria]] against the Health Commission in order to win the right to leave the institution.David J. Clark, Gerard McCoy, "Habeas corpus: Australia, New Zealand, the South Pacific", pp. 120, Federation Press, Sydney (2000), {{ISBN|1-86287-302-X}}Susan Hayes and Robert Hayes, "Simply Criminal", pp. 51, The Law Book Company Limited, Sydney (1984), {{ISBN|0-455-20279-6}} The court accepted that McDonald's communication was her own and allowed her to leave the hospital and live with Crossley. After leaving the institution, McDonald got her [[Higher School Certificate (Victoria)|Higher School Certificate]] (University entrance) qualification at night school and went on to take a humanities degree at [[Deakin University]], completed in 1993. An editorial in the Melbourne Herald-Sun said at the time: "If walking on the moon was a giant leap for mankind as well as a small step for one man, then Anne McDonald's graduation from university yesterday was a major lessor for society as much as it was the fulfilment of a personal dream".Editorial, Sunday Herald Sun, May 29, 1994 She was credited as an authored of a number of articles and papers on disability, presented at international conferences, and as being active in the disability rights movement, with special emphasis on the right to communicate.[http://home.vicnet.net.au/~dealcc/Anne2.htm Alternate home website] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090615172129/http://home.vicnet.net.au/~dealcc/Anne2.htm|date=15 June 2009}}[http://severedisabilitykid.blogspot.com/2009/10/anne-mcdonald-growth-attenuation-been.html Intelligence goes beyond motor skill]Facebook page [www.facebook.com/pages/Anne-McDonald/133281970040595] McDonald was credited as a co-author, with Crossley, of the book ''Annie's Coming Out'' (1980), which tells their story. The film ''[[Annie's Coming Out]]'', based on the book, won several [[Australian Film Institute]] awards (including Best Picture) and was released in the US under the title ''Test of Love''. It won the inaugural Allen Lane Award for the best book of the year dealing with disability. Some questioned whether McDonald had the capacity write a book, and she had to demonstrate her abilities in the Supreme Court to win the right to manage her own financial affairs and enter into a contract with Penguin Books.Rosemary Crossley, "Speechless: Facilitating Communication for People Without Voices", Dutton Adult (1997), {{ISBN|0-525-94156-8}}[http://home.vicnet.net.au/~dealcc/DwyerB.htm ACCESS TO JUSTICE FOR PEOPLE WITH SEVERE COMMUNICATION IMPAIRMENT] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101124070333/http://home.vicnet.net.au/~dealcc/DwyerB.htm|date=24 November 2010}} On the [[International Day of Persons with Disabilities]], 3 December 2008, McDonald received the Personal Achievement Award in the Australian National Disability Awards at Parliament House. Her presentation on that occasion said:
The worst thing about being an inspiration is that you have to be perfect. I am a normal person with only normal courage. Some people who should know better have tried to give me a halo. Anybody could have done what I have done if they too had been taken out of hell as I was. If you let other people without speech be helped as I was helped they will say more than I can say. They will tell you that the humanity we share is not dependent on speech. They will tell you that the power of literacy lies within us all. They will tell you that I am not an exception, only a bad example.
McDonald died of a heart attack on 22 October 2010.[http://www.theage.com.au/victoria/annie-has-gone-but-her-legacy-and-fighting-spirit-live-on-20101029-177h2.html "annie-has-gone-but-her-legacy-and-fighting-spirit-live-on"]. ''[[The Age]]'' She received a posthumous award from the Australian Group on Severe Communication Impairment (AGOSCI). The citation read:
Anne's dedicated advocacy and activism for the human rights of people with disabilities and especially those using alternative and augmentative communication (AAC) was as inspirational as her own achievement. As author and presenter she worked tirelessly to raise the profile of people with communication disabilities. Her outstanding achievements are acknowledged and sincerely appreciated by AGOSCI.Sue Owen, Chairperson, Agosci, 14 May 2011
== Controversy == The story of McDonald's use of facilitated communication has been questioned many times, with sceptics pointing to input from the assistant.{{Cite web|title = More Doubts over Disability ‘Miracle’ {{!}} Disability Advocacy Resource Unit (DARU)|url = http://www.daru.org.au/resource/more-doubts-over-disability-miracle|website = www.daru.org.au|access-date = 2016-01-16}}{{Cite news|url=http://u.b5z.net/i/u/10196230/f/LISA_Rosemarys_Baby.pdf |title=Rosemary's Baby |last=Rule |first=Andrew |date=May 14, 2012 |work= |access-date=Jan 16, 2016 |via= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160405210726/http://u.b5z.net/i/u/10196230/f/LISA_Rosemarys_Baby.pdf |archivedate=5 April 2016 }} Psychologists and policy makers have argued facilitated communication is, at best, ineffective wishful thinking, and at worst, actively harmful.{{Cite news|title = Facilitated Communication Is a Cult That Won’t Die|url = http://www.slate.com/articles/health_and_science/medical_examiner/2015/11/facilitated_communication_pseudoscience_harms_people_with_disabilities.html|newspaper = Slate|date = 2015-11-12|access-date = 2016-01-16|issn = 1091-2339|language = en-US|first = David|last = [[David Auerbach|Auerbach]]}}{{Cite web|title = FRONTLINE: previous reports: transcripts: prisoners of silence {{!}} PBS|url = https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/pages/frontline/programs/transcripts/1202.html|website = www.pbs.org|access-date = 2016-01-16}}{{Cite book|title = Research Report 77: Educational Interventions for Children With Autism: A Literature Review of Recent And Current Research|last = Jordan|first = Rita|publisher = Department for Education and Employment|year = 1998|isbn = |location = |pages = }} McDonald and her story have reappeared in the news following the sexual assault case against facilitated communication aide [[Anna Stubblefield]].{{Cite news|title = The Strange Case of Anna Stubblefield|url = https://www.nytimes.com/2015/10/25/magazine/the-strange-case-of-anna-stubblefield.html|newspaper = The New York Times|date = 2015-10-20|access-date = 2016-01-16|issn = 0362-4331|first = Daniel|last = Engber}} == Related reading == * ''Annie's Coming Out'' (Penguin Books, 1980) {{ISBN|0-14-005688-2}} ==References== {{Reflist}}{{Refimprove|date=August 2007}} Add to fn 3: The Queen and the Health Commission of Victoria, George Lipton and Dennis McGinn, ex parte Anne McDonald, Unreported Victoria Supreme Court [1979]. ==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20101101105052/http://www.deal.org.au/rowing-upstream-0 Anne McDonald: Home Page] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20101101105047/http://www.deal.org.au/right-communicate-0 The Right to Communicate] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20101102162138/http://www.deal.org.au/anne-14-years-st-nicholas My Years In Hell] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20101102142122/http://www.deal.org.au/anne-my-frankenstein My Frankenstein] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20101101105015/http://www.deal.org.au/anne-if-we-keep-babies-alive What I Think Of Euthanasia] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20101102142126/http://www.deal.org.au/anne-proving-i-exist I've only got one life to live, and I don't want to waste it all proving I exist] * [http://members.optusnet.com.au/~anne.mcdonald/Anne_files/Anne_update.html "To thyself be enough."] * [https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0088250/ IMDB link to the film Annie's Coming Out] * [https://openlibrary.org/books/OL3726207M/Annie's_coming_out/ Annie's Coming Out], freely available as eBook on Open Library. {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:McDonald, Anne}} [[Category:1961 births]] [[Category:Australian memoirists]] [[Category:Australian non-fiction writers]] [[Category:Australian disability rights activists]] [[Category:Australian people with disabilities]] revision.text:
{{rough translation|1=Spanish|listed=yes|date=October 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2014}} {{Infobox criminal | name = Antonio Anglés | caption = | birth_name = Antonio Anglés Martins | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1966|7|25|df=y}} | birth_place = [[São Paulo]], Brazil | death_date = [[1993]]? | death_place = [[Ireland]]? | death_cause = [[Drowning]]? | disappeared_date = {{Disappeared date and age|1993|3|18|1966|7|25}} | disappeared_place = Ireland? | disappeared_status = {{Missing for|1993|03|18}} | nationality = [[Spain|Spanish]] and [[Brazil]]ian | height = {{convert|5|ft|9|in}} | occupation = [[Electrician]] | conviction = [[Kidnapping]], [[rape]], [[murder]], [[Weapon|illegal possession of weapons]] and unlawful burials | reward_amount = | capture_status = Not caught | victims = [[Alcasser Girls]] }}
'''Antonio Anglés Martins''' (born 25 July 1966 in [[São Paulo]], [[Brazil]]) is a [[Spain|Spanish]] [[Crime|criminal]] and fugitive. He lived in his birth country for a year before moving to [[Spain]]. According to his relatives and friends, Anglés was known as a habitually violent [[criminal]] who frequently beat up his mother. With criminal records for [[wikt:mugging|mugging]], [[robbery]] and [[drug trafficking]], he is best known for his triple offense, "[[The Alcasser Girls|Crime of Alcácer]]", committed in [[Alcácer]], a town in the [[Valencia]]n region, in which [[Desirée Hernández Folch|Desirée Hernández]], [[Miriam García Iborra|Miriam García]], and [[Antonia Gómez Rodríguez|Antonia Gómez]] were allegedly [[Kidnapping|kidnapped]], [[torture]]d, [[rape]]d and [[Murder|killed]] by Anglés.
== Life == Some raised doubts about the July 25, 1966 date of Anglés Martins' birth at São Paulo because the reports of the Spanish Civil Guards and the Police show different dates.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://elcrimendealcasser.wordpress.com/antonio-angles-martins/|title=Antonio Anglés Martins|date=2014-12-04|work=El crimen de Alcàsser|access-date=2018-06-05|language=es-ES}}</ref> Aside from this discrepancy, however, his early life has been documented. His parents were Enrique Anglés and Neusa Martins, who were married in February 1959. The couple had nine children and Anglés Martins was the fourth. By 1958, the family transferred to Spain where they resided in Valencia town called Catarroja. Sources show that Anglés Martins started living on his own in 1991 when he moved to number 101 Camí Real Street.
He spent two years in [[prison]] for kidnapping, chaining and hitting 20-year-old [[Nuria Pera Mateu]] in January 1990, apparently for stealing some grams of [[heroin]] from him. The woman's life was saved thanks to the intervention of one of Anglés’ brothers. Given a chance for social reintegration, he received penitentiary leave of six days in 1992, and he took advantage of it to escape, with the result that he didn't finish his sentence and he was from that point on arrest warrant.
== The Alcácer crime == '''Reconstruction of events'''
On the night of November 13, 1992 Antonio Anglés, well known as ''Asukiki'' or "Sugar", went for a drive in the [[Opel Corsa]] of his friend [[Miguel Ricart Tárrega]] ([[Catarroja]], 1969) who was with him. While they were driving along the road they saw three girls who were [[hitchhiking]] to a party which the Picasent High School was holding in the nightclub ''Coolor''. Anglés asked them if they were going to the nightclub ''Coolor'' and so the three girls got into the car.
When they arrived at the nightclub ''Coolor'', Anglés told Ricart to continue driving. The girls started screaming. Right after, Anglés pulled out a [[9 mm]] short caliber ''[[Star Bonifacio Echeverria|Star]]'' gun. He hit them with the butt of the gun and then he tied them up. ''El Rubio'', as people called Ricart, drove the car to [[Catadau]]. This was the area where Anglés used to hide when the [[Guardia Civil]] were looking for him. He suggested the half fallen hut<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.elespanol.com/reportajes/grandes-historias/20171112/261474386_0.html|title=El caserón de Alcàsser 25 años después: aquí asesinaron a las niñas|last=López Frías|first=David|date=November 2017|website=El Español|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> of ''La Romana'' as a place to take the girls. Two of the girls were raped by both Anglés and Ricart. Later, they decided to tie them up and return to the town to look for food. When they came back, they raped the third girl and then they dug a pit and obliged them to go there, where they shot and buried them. They picked up the cartridges of the gun and cleaned the car.
'''Ensuing days'''
An intense search to find the girls began. On January 27, 1993, after heavy rains, the soil softened and the bodies appeared. Two [[beekeepers]] who were taking care of their beehives ([[Gabriel Aquino]] and [[José Sala Sala]], 69 and 53 years old respectively) came across the pit. In the investigation, the [[Guardia Civil]] found one of Ricart's gloves, a [[social security]] slip in the name of [[Enrique Anglés Martins]], Antonio's brother, and a gun cartridge in the pit.
Anglés was not in his house when the ''Guardia Civil'' went there looking for his brother Enrique. He escaped and hid for a month in a Valencian town, harassed by the Guardia Civil and the [[police]]. He was almost captured in {{Interlanguage link multi|Villamarchante|es}}, but he managed to escape the extensive police cordon which had been set up. He appeared again in [[Minglanilla, Cuenca|Minglanilla]] ([[Cuenca, Spain|Cuenca]]) some days later, the last place in [[Spain]] where he was seen before being subsequently spotted in [[Lisbon]] in March 1993. From this point on, there are two theories: The first says that he boarded the [[boat]] ''[[City of Plymouth]]'' as a stowaway, before jumping overboard on being discovered near the coast of [[Ireland]]. Thereafter, his trail was lost, and he is believed to have died from cold or drowning in those waters. The second theory simply assumes that in Lisbon he boarded a ship for [[Brazil]], his native country, and he managed to get there and enter the country with his Brazilian passport, since he had dual nationality (Spanish and Brazilian), but the reality is that until the present day nothing is known about his whereabouts.
After 21 years in prison, Ricart was released on November 29, 2013 and was reported to have given a series of interviews in which he still maintained his innocence, alleging a conspiracy that pinned him as scapegoat.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.lasprovincias.es/sucesos/201512/10/miguel-ricart-anos-anonimato-20151210121807.html|title=Miguel Ricart, dos años en el anonimato|date=2015-12-10|work=Las Provincias|access-date=2018-06-05|language=es-ES}}</ref> However, he did not return to prison, and still remains at large. According to Interpol's records, Antonio Anglés Martins is still included in its most wanted criminals list. He is described in its database as 1.75 meters tall and has blue eyes. He is charged with kidnapping, rape, murder, unlawful burial, and illegal possession of weapons.
== See also == * [[The Alcasser Girls]] * [[List of fugitives from justice who disappeared]]
== References == * {{cite book | last = Pérez Abellán | first = Francisco | title = Alcácer, punto final: toda la verdad diez años después | date = 2002 | publisher = Barcelona: Martínez Roca | isbn =84-270-2913-6 }} * ''F.P.A. Libertad digital suplementos. "El asesinato de las niñas de Alcàsser, violación y más hechos"''. [https://web.archive.org/web/20050530004135/http://findesemana.libertaddigital.com/articulo.php/1276230201] * ''S.B. El País. "Catarroja pide perdón"''. [http://elpais.com/diario/1993/02/01/espana/728521203_850215.html] * ''M.A./S.V. El País. "Antonio Anglés, retrato de un superviviente"''. [http://elpais.com/diario/2002/04/14/cvalenciana/1018811889_850215.html] * {{cite book | last = Martínez Laínez | first = Fernando | title = Sin piedad | date = 1993 | publisher = Barcelona: Ediciones B | isbn= 84-406-4178-8 }} * ''R.B.C. ABC. "Los delitos de Anglés no prescribirán hasta 2029"''. [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/madrid/abc/2013/04/25/029.html] *P. Muñoz (30 November 2013). "Interpol mantiene a Antonio Anglés entre los delincuentes más buscados del mundo". ABC. {{Reflist}}
== External links == * [https://plus.google.com/photos/108892518390484656701/albums?banner=pwa Completed Photo Albums in Picasa of photographies in "La Romana" (2008-2010-2011)] * [http://boards5.melodysoft.com/app?ID=elpalleter Forum Alcasser Case] * [https://www.panoramio.com/map/?user=4899913#lt=39.242395&ln=-0.659883&z=3&k=1&a=1&tab=5&pl=all Geolocated photos "Autopsia en La Romana" (2010) about the assumed crime scene in Panoramio and Google Earth] * [http://ww12.elarchivodelcrimen.net/ Newspaper Library Alcasser Case] * [http://es.scribd.com/doc/5704216/Caso-Alcasser-Autopsia-en-La-Romana Report on "Autopsia en La Romana" (2008) about the assumed crime scene] * [https://www.youtube.com/user/PepeCriminologo#p/u Videos "Autopsia en La Romana" (2010-2011) about the assumed crime scene in Youtube]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Angles, Antonio}} [[Category:1966 births]] [[Category:1990s missing person cases]] [[Category:Missing people]] [[Category:Missing person cases in Ireland]] [[Category:People from Valencia]] [[Category:Spanish assassins]] [[Category:Spanish expatriates]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2015}} {{Use Australian English|date=June 2015}} {{Infobox writer | name = Barry Dickins | image = | caption = | birth_date = 1949 | birth_place = [[Reservoir, Victoria|Reservoir]], [[Melbourne]] | occupation = Playwright
Author
Artist
Actor | nationality = Australian | notableworks = ''[https://trove.nla.gov.au/work/30768544 Remember Ronald Ryan]'' | spouse = Sarah Mogridge (div. 2008)Dickins, Barry; Unparalleled Sorrow: Finding My Way Back From Depression; Hardie Grant Books; 2009 | children = Louis Dickins | imagesize = | influences = | influenced = }} '''Barry Dickins''' (born 1949) is a prolific Australian playwright, author, artist, actor, educator and journalist, probably best known for his historical dramas and his reminisces about growing up and living in working class Melbourne.{{cite web |title=Writer in residence – Barry Dickins |date=21 April 2015 |publisher=Victoria University |url=https://www.vu.edu.au/news-events/events/writer-in-residence-barry-dickins}} His most well-known work is the award winning stage play ''Remember Ronald Ryan'', a dramatization of the life and subsequent death of [[Ronald Ryan]], the last man executed in Australia. He has also written dramas and comedies about other controversial figures like poet [[Sylvia Plath]],{{cite news |date=14 September 2013 |title=Theatre review: A Kind of Fabulous Hatred |author=Cameron Woodhead |newspaper=The Sydney Morning Herald |url=http://www.smh.com.au/entertainment/theatre/theatre-review-a-kind-of-fabulous-hatred-20130913-2tq4e.html}} opera singer [[Joan Sutherland]],{{cite web |title=Dame Joan Green |date=3 May 1995 |publisher=AusStage |url=https://ausstage.edu.au/pages/event/29332}} criminal [[Squizzy Taylor]],{{cite news |title=Squizzy: Legendary Melbourne gangster Squizzy Taylor's life as musical theatre |author=Cameron Woodhead |date=13 June 2006 |newspaper=The Age |url=http://www.theage.com.au/news/arts-reviews/squizzy/2006/06/13/1149964507914.html}} actor [[Frank Thring]],{{cite news |title=The Real Thring |author=Martin Ball |date=15 September 2008 |newspaper=The Age |url=http://www.theage.com.au/news/arts-reviews/the-real-thring/2008/09/15/1221330703503.html}} playwright [[Oscar Wilde]]{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/rn/legacy/programs/atoday/stories/s133053.htm|title=Barry Dickens, Believe Me, Oscar Wilde|website=www.abc.net.au}} and artist [[Brett Whiteley]].{{cite web |title=Playwright's addiction to an Australian art great: Barry Dickins interview with The Age |date=4 October 2011 |author=Robin Usher |publisher=fortyfivedownstairs |url=http://www.fortyfivedownstairs.com/wp2016/news/playwrights-addiction-to-an-australian-art-great-barry-dickins-interview-with-the-age/}} reprinted from {{cite news |title=Playwright's addiction to an Australian art great |author=Robin Usher |date=1 October 2011 |newspaper=The Age}} Dickins primarily writes for Australia's independent theatre scene, frequently collaborating with [[La Mama Theatre (Melbourne)|La Mama Theatre]], [[Malthouse Theatre, Melbourne|Malthouse Theatre]], [[The Pram Factory]], [[Griffin Theatre Company]], [[fortyfivedownstairs]] and [[St Martins Youth Arts Centre|St Martin Youth Theatre]].{{cite web |title=Barry Dickins |publisher=AusStage |url=https://ausstage.edu.au/pages/contributor/417}} ==Biography== He was born in the [[Melbourne]] suburb of [[Reservoir, Victoria|Reservoir]].{{cite web | last = | first = | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = Dickins, Barry (a.k.a. Dickins, Barry Leonard ) | publisher = AusLit Database | url = http://www.austlit.edu.au/run?ex=ShowAgent&agentId=A(dH | accessdate = 2007-03-21 }} Leaving school early he worked for five years in a factory in [[North Melbourne, Victoria|North Melbourne]], and then as a set-painter for television programs being produced at [[Seven Network|Channel 7]].{{cite web|url=https://www.vu.edu.au/news-events/events/writer-in-residence-barry-dickins|title=Writer in residence – Barry Dickins - Victoria University - Melbourne Australia|website=www.vu.edu.au}} Through his association with [[La Mama Theatre (Melbourne)|La Mama Theatre]], his first play, a translation of Ibsen's ''[[Ghosts (play)|Ghosts]]'', was performed in 1974.{{cite web|url=http://www.doollee.com/PlaywrightsD/dickins-barry.html|title=doollee.com - the playwrights database of modern plays|website=www.doollee.com}} He has written a further 50 since then, along with numerous short stories, biographies, opinion pieces, essays and children's books.{{cite web|url=https://www.vu.edu.au/news-events/news/writer-barry-dickins-shares-his-story-in-footscray-university-town|title=Writer Barry Dickins shares his story in Footscray University Town - Victoria University - Melbourne Australia|website=www.vu.edu.au}} His play ''[https://trove.nla.gov.au/work/30768544 Remember Ronald Ryan]'' won him the 1995 [[Victorian Premier's Literary Award]]. He has also had a long career as an educator, spending 41 years teaching English and creative writing at various schools in Melbourne (including Scotch College, Melbourne Grammar and West Preston Primary School). His experiences in the classroom served the basis for his 2013 memoirs, ''Lessons in Humility: 40 years of teaching''.{{cite web|url=https://www.theage.com.au/education/barry-dickins-seasons-greetings-and-a-casual-goodbye-from-victoria-university-20151120-gl3lgi.html|title=Barry Dickins: Seasons greetings and a casual goodbye|first=Barry|last=Dickins|date=20 November 2015|website=The Age}}{{cite web|url=http://www.smh.com.au/entertainment/books/lessons-in-humility-40-years-of-teaching-20130222-2ewb3.html|title=Lessons in humility: 40 years of teaching|first=Reviewed by Ross|last=Fitzgerald|date=23 February 2013|website=The Sydney Morning Herald}} Dickins has made numerous appearances on the stage and on the screen. His first acting role was in [[Barry Oakley]]'s ''The Ship's Whistles'', which was staged in 1978 at the [[The Pram Factory|Pram Factory Front Theatre]], under the direction of Paul Hampton.{{cite web|url=https://ausstage.edu.au/pages/event/30297|title=AusStage|website=ausstage.edu.au}} Since then he has appeared in: [[Paul Cox (director)|Paul Cox's]] ''[[Man of Flowers]]'' (1983); [[James Clayden|James Clayden's]] ''[[With Time to Kill]]'' (1987); Brian McKenzie's ''[[With Love to the Person Next to Me]]'' (1987);{{cite web |url=https://www.screenaustralia.gov.au/the-screen-guide/t/with-love-to-the-person-next-to-me-1988/383/ |title=Film listing |website=screenaustralia.gov.au |publisher=The Screen Guide}} Paul Cox's ''The Gift'' (1988; Paul Cox's ''[[Golden Braid]]'' (1990) (which Dickins also co-wrote);{{cite web|url=https://www.rottentomatoes.com/celebrity/barry_dickins|title=Barry Dickins|website=www.rottentomatoes.com}} Brian McKenzie's ''People Who Steal Use Milk Bottles'' (1991);{{cite web |url=https://www.screenaustralia.gov.au/the-screen-guide/t/people-who-still-use-milk-bottles-1990/1338/|title=Film Details|website=screenaustralia.gov.au |publisher=The Screen Guide}} [[Frank Howson|Frank Howson's]] ''[[Flynn (film)|Flynn]]'' (1993); and Elise McCredie's ''[[Strange Fits of Passion]]'' (1999). He also had guest roles on the television shows ''Winners'' (1985) and ''Wedlocked'' (1995) In 1985, he appeared in a revival of [[Graeme Blundell|Graeme Blundell's]] ''Balmain Boys Don't Cry'' (renamed ''The Balmain Boys'') at the Kinsela's Cabaret Theatre in [[Darlinghurst, New South Wales]].{{cite web|url=https://www.ausstage.edu.au/pages/event/106497|title=AusStage|website=www.ausstage.edu.au}} His most recent stage performance was recent a dramatic reading of the monologue, ''Ryan'' (a continuation of his earlier work ''Remember Ronald Ryan''), which was performed as part of a QandA event held at Melbourne based bookshop, Collected Works.{{cite web|url=http://adelaidereview.com.au/opinion/irregular-writings/memories-last-man-hanged-australia-barry-dickins/|title=Memories of the Last Man Hanged In Australia with Barry Dickins - The Adelaide Review|date=12 May 2016|publisher=}} In 2009, he published his memoirs ''[https://trove.nla.gov.au/work/28571480?q&versionId=44566586+178993073 Unparalleled Sorrow]'', which discusses his career and his battle with depression.{{cite web |url=https://www.angusrobertson.com.au/books/unparalleled-sorrow-barry-dickins/p/9781740668033 |title=Book listing|website=angusrobertson.com.au |publisher=Angus & Robertson Book World}}/ 2015 saw the publication by [[Black Pepper publishing]] of ''A Line Drawing of My Father'', a memoir of the authors' father Len Dickins who served in the Second World War and was a commercial printer thereafter. It also gives a portrait of the working class northern suburbs of Melbourne. In 2015, Dickins became a Writer-in-Residence and Creative Writing lecturer at [[Victoria University, Australia|Victoria University]] in [[Footscray, Victoria|Footscray]], [[Melbourne]]. He held the position for less than 12 months, before being unexpectedly let go by the campus coordinators during the Christmas break. In June 2017 Dickins was found guilty of making a false police report after claiming officers had conducted an improper strip search upon him. The Magistrate remarked of Dickins' report "for reasons which I truly cannot fathom, Mr Dickins invented a set of facts, which were not true and, in my view, he knew them not to be true". For this Dickins was placed on a 12-month good behaviour bond with no conviction recorded.{{Cite news|url=http://www.theage.com.au/victoria/writer-found-guilty-of-making-false-report-to-victoria-police-20170602-gwj0rk.html|title=Writer found guilty of making false report to Victoria Police|date=2017-06-04|work=The Age|access-date=2017-11-04}} His then employer, [[The Sunday Age]], was later found to have breached [[Australian Press Council]] principles in lieu of their publication of Dickens' account of the alleged police misconduct.{{Cite news|url=http://www.theage.com.au/victoria/australian-press-council-complaint-from-victoria-police-upheld-20171102-gze1ff.html|title=Australian Press Council: complaint from Victoria Police upheld|date=2017-11-04|work=The Age|access-date=2017-11-04}} == Bibliography == ===Plays=== * ''Ghosts'' [from Henrik Ibsen] (1975) * ''A Season of Five Plays'' [as contributor] (AGP Women's Theatre Group 1976){{cite web|url=https://ausstage.edu.au/pages/event/124236|title=AusStage|website=ausstage.edu.au}} * ''Only An Old Kitbag'' (Australian Performing Group 1977){{cite web|url=https://www.ausstage.edu.au/pages/event/126697|title=AusStage|website=www.ausstage.edu.au}} * ''[[Biographies of Oscar Wilde#Biographical films, television series and stage plays|The Great Oscar Wilde Trial]]'' ([[La Mama Theatre (Melbourne)|La Mama Theatre]] 1977){{cite web|url=http://ausstage.edu.au/pages/event/117474|title=AusStage|website=ausstage.edu.au}} * ''The Interview'' (La Mama Theatre 1977){{cite web|url=http://ausstage.edu.au/pages/event/117477|title=AusStage|website=ausstage.edu.au}} * ''The Rotten Teeth Show'' ([[The Pram Factory|Pram Factory Theatre]] 1978){{cite web|url=http://www.theatrepeople.com.au/whiteleys-incredible-blue-interview-with-barry-dickens/|title=Whiteley's Incredible Blue -
