page.title: Third Order Regular of Saint Francis of Penance

revision.comment: Rescued 1 archive link; reformat 1 link. [[User:GreenC/WaybackMedic_2.1|Wayback Medic 2.1]]
revision.text:
The '''Third Order Regular of St. Francis of Penance''' (or '''Third Order Regular of St. Francis''') is a [[mendicant order]] rooted in the [[Third Order of St. Francis]] which was founded in 1447.
==Foundation== The twelfth century saw a marked emphasis toward the penitential life, reflected in monastic reforms of [[Romuald]] (+ 1027), and [[Peter Damian]] among others.<ref name=Muscat>[https://web.archive.org/web/19970607200759/http://www.christusrex.org/www1/ofm/fra/FRAht11.html Muscat, Noel ofm. "History of the Franciscan movement", FIOR (Franciscan Institute Outreach - Malta)]</ref> The Third Order Regular developed from the Third Order Secular movement which arose in the early 13th century from the convergence of groups of penitents who were inspired by the life of [[Francis of Assisi]]. Sometime between 1209 and 1220, Saint Francis communicated with some of these groups through a series of letters entitled the "Exhortations to the Brothers and Sisters of Penance". In 1221 Francis asked Cardinal [[Pope Gregory IX|Ugolino di Conti]] to draft a rule for lay people whose personal circumstances precluded their joining a religious order such as the [[Friars Minor]] or the [[Poor Clares]]. These individuals formed the [[Third Order of Saint Francis]] and were called "tertiaries".<ref name=Robinson>[http://www.newadvent.org/cathen/06217a.htm Robinson, Paschal. "Franciscan Order." The Catholic Encyclopedia] Vol. 6. New York: Robert Appleton Company, 1909. 17 June 2016</ref>
The organized form of this life, though, can be more reliably traced back to the second half of the thirteenth century. In 1289 the first Franciscan pope, [[Pope Nicholas IV]] decided to recognize the Third Order of San Francis in a formal manner. He gave approval to the Order of Penance, and reissued the “Memoriale Propositi”, the Rule of 1221 in a more juridic form. Those Penitent Franciscans who remained in their homes (married or single) constituted the Secular Third Order (TOS), which since 1978 has been called the Secular Franciscan Order (OFS).<ref name=Quinn>[http://www.franciscanfriarstor.com/aboutus.php Quinn, Pat T.O.R., "TOR History", Franciscan Friars TOR, Province of Immaculate Conception]</ref>
Some secular tertiaries, who in many cases had their house of meeting, gradually withdrew entirely from the world and so formed religious communities, but without the three vows of religious orders. Some of the penitents began to live communal life dedicating themselves to works of mercy; others began to live in remote places as hermits. Members of religious organizations, such as the [[Beguines]] (women) and [[Beghards]] (men) in the Low Countries, sometimes joined the Third Order. These groups were known as the Religious of the Third Order Regular of St. Francis.<ref>[http://www.franciscanfriarstor.com/archive/theorder/ Franciscans Third Order Regular - Rome]</ref>
==History== In 1295, [[Pope Boniface VIII]] promulgated the papal bull ''Cupientes cultum'' which approved the style of community life of the tertiaries and the pastoral ministry they offered to the people. He permitted the brothers of penitence (Tertiaries) of northern Germany, to live in community and have oratories in their houses in order to celebrate the divine office. The aim of these fraternities was normally that of taking care of hospitals.<ref name=Muscat/>
By the fifteenth century tertiary communities of men and women existed in different parts of Europe.<ref name=Robinson/> In 1447, [[Pope Nicholas V]] united the eremitical communities in Umbria and the Marches which followed the Third Order rule into a single community under a minister general. This community of men is one part of the Third Order Regular. The order spread throughout Italy. To introduce uniformity to the numerous congregations, in 1521 [[Pope Leo X]] gave a new form to the Rule, retaining much of the Rule published by Nicholas IV and adding new points, especially the three solemn vows of poverty, chastity and obedience.<ref name=Muscat/>
In several countries there was a gradual development of national tertiary orders. Some orders disappeared due to government suppression or war, while others joined with the Italian congregation in a single entity which today is called the Third Order Regular of Saint Francis. The French congregation maintained close ties with the First Order until its extinction during the French Revolution.
===Ireland=== The history of the Third Order Regular in Ireland dates back to the later part of the 14th and early part of the 15th centuries. These tertiary communities were small groups of clerical and lay brothers. The Franciscan Brothers of the Third Order Regular, noted for their having secretly taught the boys of the Catholic population of Ireland for decades in the underground "bog schools", established a monastery and school at Milltown, Dublin, after the relaxation of the Penal Laws which had forbidden Catholic education. In 1818 they transferred their monastery to Mountbellew in County Galway, where the Bellew family had invited them and had donated land and a house to get established. The Brothers ran a free primary school and specialized in trade schools for young men.<ref>[http://www.franciscanbrothersosf.org/our-community/our-history/ Higgins, Michael T.O.R., ""Our History", Franciscan Brothers of Brooklyn]</ref>
===United States=== In the mid-19th century, in response to the request from bishops in the United States, the Brothers accepted apostolic works outside of Ireland. A group of Franciscan Brothers from the community at Mountbellew traveled to the United States to minister as teachers and established permanent foundations in Loretto, Pennsylvania, Brooklyn, New York, and Spaulding, Nebraska.
There are two provinces in the United States: The Province of the Most Sacred Heart of Jesus, Loretto, Pennsylvania, and the Province of the Immaculate Conception, Hollidaysburg, Pennsylvania. The Sacred Heart Province focused its efforts on education and developed what is now Saint Francis University and The Franciscan University in Steubenville, Ohio. The Province of the Immaculate Conception was formed out of the need to serve Italian immigrants who came to Pennsylvania to work on the railroad, in the mines, or in steel mills. Eventually, the communities in Pennsylvania and Nebraska were permitted by their bishops to seek consolidation with the friars of the Third Order Regular, by then based in Rome. Papal permission was granted and in 1908, the two communities were incorporated into the Order, and in 1910 were established as the autonomous American Province of the Sacred Heart of the Franciscan Friars of the Third Order Regular.
==== Province of the Sacred Heart of Jesus ==== Prior to 1906, three separate and independent communities of men of the Third Order Regular existed in the United States. All of them were institutes of [[lay brothers]] dedicated to teaching and other works of charity. These were located in [[Brooklyn, New York]] (1858); [[Loretto, Pennsylvania]] (1847); and [[Spalding, Nebraska]], which came about from a school founded for [[Indigenous peoples of the Americas|Native American]] boys (ca. 1882), at the request of [[Bishop]] [[John Ireland (archbishop)|John Ireland]]. The communities at Loretto and Brooklyn had been founded from [[Mountbellew]] Monastery, in [[Tuam]], [[County Galway]], [[Ireland]], at the request of the bishops of Brooklyn and Pittsburgh, respectively. The community in Nebraska was a branch of the Brooklyn community.<ref name=Jarrett>[http://www.newadvent.org/cathen/14637b.htm Jarrett, Bede, Ferdinand Heckmann, Benedict Zimmerman, Livarius Oliger, Odoric Jouve, Lawrence Hess, and John Doyle. "Third Orders." The Catholic Encyclopedia] Vol. 14. New York: Robert Appleton Company, 1912. 13 June 2016</ref>
As communities of lay Brothers, they were under the authority of their local bishops, who acted [[canon law|canonically]] as the [[superior general]] of the community within their [[diocese]]. The Brothers, however, came to desire a closer connection with the wider Franciscan Order. Additionally, due to the desire of some of the Brothers for [[ordination]], as well as seeing a need to have the [[pastoral care]] of both the Brothers and their students coming from within their community, Brothers Raphael Brehenny, O.S.F., and his successor, Brother Linus Lynch, O.S.F., the superiors of the Brooklyn community, asked the bishop of that diocese for permission to have some of the members of that community ordained as [[priesthood (Catholic Church)|priests]]. This request the bishop refused, as the community had been introduced into the diocese for the care of parish schools, and the bishop feared that in the event of its members becoming priests this work would suffer. Thus, in May 1906, a petition was then sent to the [[minister general]], the [[Most Rev.]] [[Father (title)|Fr.]] Angelus de Mattia, T.O.R., asking for union with the [[friar]]s of the Third Order Regular of St. Francis in Italy. The [[Roman Catholic Bishop of Brooklyn|Bishop of Brooklyn]], however, worked actively to block this effort, and it was halted.<ref name=Jarrett/>
In November of that same year, the Spalding community made the same request to Fr. Angelo, the minister general in Rome. In their case, however, the local bishop was in accord with their desire and gave his authorization for such a merger. The following December 8, the minister general, Fr. Angelo, signed a decree of union of the Spalding community with the Third Order Regular. In January 1907, he formally petitioned the [[Holy See]] to allow the establishment of a community of the Order in Nebraska, and to receive the vows of any qualified Brothers there. This was granted immediately, with the official approval and blessing of Pope Saint [[Pius X]] being formally declared that following November. The Brothers were received into the Order by Fr. Stanislaus Dujmoric, T.O.R., of the [[Ecclesiastical Province|Province]] of [[Dalmatia]], who had been sent as the official delegate of the minister general to supervise the merger.<ref name=Jarrett/>
As their own union could not be effected, some of the Brooklyn Brothers determined to ask for a dispensation from their [[religious vows]] in order to join the friars in Nebraska. In the spring of 1907, several left New York and transferred to Spalding. The former superior, Bro. Raphael, appears to have been among them. That July, led by Bro. Linus, 23 Brothers also left Brooklyn and went to Spalding. At that point, the Nebraska community had increased from the initial size of six to thirty. Relying heavily upon the teaching experience of the New York Brothers, the community opened Spalding College in January 1908.
During that year of upheaval for the Brooklyn foundation, the diocesan community of Franciscan Brothers at Loretto—now in the new [[Roman Catholic Diocese of Altoona-Johnstown|Diocese of Altoona]]—also sought incorporation with the Third Order Regular friars with the approval of their bishop, the Rt. Rev. [[Eugene A. Garvey]]. This was done on December 29, 1907. Permission for their admission received papal approval on May 22, 1908, and the union was achieved on May 28. To oversee this process, the minister general in Rome sent Fr. Jerome Zazzara, T.O.R., as his delegate, assisted by Fr. Anthony Balastieri, T.O.R. Brother Raphael and three other Brothers came from Spalding to help in the process.
At the request of Bishop Garvey, who was struggling to meet the needs of [[Italian (language)|Italian-speaking]] Catholics, Fr. Jerome accepted charge of the Church of St. Anthony of Padua at [[Johnstown, Pennsylvania]], in November 1909 as a permanent [[Christian ministry|ministry]] of the friars, appointing his fellow [[Italian (people)|Italian]], Fr. Anthony, as [[pastor]]. With the establishment of a small community of friars in that parish, there now existed three separate communities in the United States, the minimum canonically required for an independent province. The following month, Fr. Jerome also accepted the Church of Our Lady of Mount Carmel, [[Altoona, Pennsylvania]], and took on the office of pastor himself.
The four houses in the United States were erected into a province, 24 September 1910, under the title of the Province of the Most Sacred Heart of Jesus. Fr. Jerome was appointed as the first [[Provincial superior|minister provincial]]. The [[Archbishop of Chicago]] later gave the friars charge of Sts. Peter and Paul Slavic Church in that city, and a new college was to be opened at Sioux City, Iowa, in 1912. At that point, the American Province had five [[friary|friaries]], two colleges, 65 professed members, and 20 [[novice]]s and [[postulant]]s. Fr. Raphael Brehenny, original superior of the Brooklyn Brothers, was elected the first native minister provincial in 1913. The provincial motherhouse is at [[St. Francis University]], Loretto, Pennsylvania.
==== Province of the Immaculate Conception ==== The other province, Immaculate Conception, has its headquarters at St. Bernadine Monastery in [[Hollidaysburg, Pennsylvania]]. This province came about as the result of a dispute over the eligibility of the Italian friars to vote in the Provincial [[Chapter (religion)|Chapter]] of 1918. The Minister General was unable to oversee the proceedings due to the hostilities between the United States and Italy during [[World War I]]. He thus appointed an American friar as his Delegate, who oversaw that Chapter. This friar declared that the foreign friars still belonged to their Italian provinces and thus were ineligible to vote in the Chapter. These friars, along with some Americans, refused to accept the election of a new Minister Provincial which took place. This resulted in the newly elected Minister Provincial and the then-current one both claiming the office.
The matter was referred to the [[Sacred Congregation]] in Rome. That office declared that, for the sake of peace, a new Chapter should be held under the presidency of a friar from another Province, and that the Italian friars should declare their intention to transfer formally from their original Provinces. That Chapter, held in 1919, resulted in the same results as the previous one. By that time, however, discontent among the Italian friars and others was so deep that the Italian friars and their supporters petitioned to form a separate [[Commissariat]] (a semi-autonomous division in the Order). This was approved in 1920, and the new Commissariat numbered thirteen friars—five Italians and eight Americans. Fr. Jerome was appointed Commissary Provincial.
Five years later, the Dalmatian friar, Fr. Stanislaus, who had supervised the union of the Spalding community into the Order was now Minister General. He raised the Commissariat to the status of a Province. Fr. Jerome was elected the first Minister Provincial. The Province still staffs the two original parishes in [[Pennsylvania]], as well as two in [[Minnesota]]. It also runs retreat centers in [[Orlando, Florida]] and [[West Virginia]]. The current Minister Provincial (2010) is the Very Rev. J. Patrick Quinn, T.O.R. In 1920, the Province divided and the Province of the Immaculate Conception were established. Friars from the [[Spain|Spanish]] Province were invited to the United States to work with the [[Spanish language|Spanish-speaking]] populations of Texas and New York.
A number of the Brothers in Brooklyn also sought to join the congregation in Italy, but were denied permission by the local bishop, who was concerned that he might lose services as teachers. The Brooklyn foundation became the [[Franciscan Brothers of Brooklyn]].
In 1938, American friars were sent to establish the Order's first [[mission (station)|foreign missions]] in [[Bhagalpur]], [[India]], and later a mission was founded in [[Paraguay]].<ref>[http://www.franciscanway.org/sacredhearthistory.html "History", Sacred Heart Province]</ref>
=== Philippines === Towards the end of the 1980s the [http://www.provinciasanfrancescotor.it/ TOR Province of Assisi, Italy], promoted vocations in the [[Philippines]]. Four young men replied to the invitation. Out of the four, two became priests, Fr. Dante Anhao and Fr. Milestone Japin. Fr. Dante Anhao (still a deacon at that time) together with Fr. Carlo Stradaioli and Fr. Marcello Fadda, came to the Philippines in 1997. They were welcomed by Bishop Emilio Bataclan, DD, the Ordinary of the [[Roman Catholic Diocese of Iligan|Diocese of Iligan]]. This was the beginning of the TOR Philippine Mission under the Assisi Province.
The small community of three friars has grown in number as some young men came and received formation. Fr. Nilo Laput, a diocesan priest, who stayed with a local Franciscan community in [[Labason, Zamboanga del Norte]], through the invitation of former Minister General, the late Most Rev. Fr. Bonaventure Midili, TOR came to join the new community in 1999. He received his novitiate formation in Assisi, Italy. Alvin Galicia, a former member of Fr. Laput’s community in Labason, came later and also did his novitiate formation in Italy.
At first the friars and their candidates lived in two semi-concrete houses before the establishment of a permanent friary and formation house in 2005. By this time, the temporary professed friars studied theology at [http://www.sjvts.org/ St. John Vianney Theological Seminary] (SJVTS) in [[Cagayan de Oro]], a city about eighty kilometers from Iligan. In 2007, Fr. George Mailadil, TOR, a friar from Ranchi Province, India, came to help in the formation of the friars in theology in Cagayan de Oro.
In 2009, with the support of Fr. George Mailadil, it was decided that the theological studies of the Junior Friars will be transferred from Saint John Vianney Theological Seminary (SJVTS) to St. Alphonsus Theological and Mission Institute (SATMI) in [[Davao City]]. Davao City is around four thousand kilometers away from Iligan or Cagayan de Oro. At first, they were renting a house in the city while a simple house was constructed in a two-hectare land in Indangan.
On January 6, 2012, the small TOR Philippine Mission was raised to the status of a Delegation. By this, we are now directly under the [http://www.francescanitor.org/?lang=en TOR Generalate in Rome] in terms of administration and decisions. The statutes of the new delegation was drafted and was approved by the General Minister on March 20, 2012. The name of the new delegation is '''The Delegation of Saints Cosmas and Damian.'''<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.torpilipinas.com/sts-cosmas-damian|title=Franciscan TOR - Philippines|website=Franciscan TOR - Philippines|access-date=2017-02-10}}</ref>
==Contemporary TOR== As the traditional spirituality of the Third Order Regular derives from the Franciscan Penitence Movement the specification “de poenitentia” is always added beside the name of the Order.
The Basilica of Sts. Cosmas and Damian, Rome, is the home of the central government of the Order under the direction of a Minister General. The Order is divided into several provinces composed of friars, (brothers). Some of the friars are ordained priests or studying for ordination, but ordination is not necessary to be a member of the Order. Every six years elected representatives from the Provinces meet in General Chapter to elect the Minister General and his Council and to make decisions for the whole Order.
As of 2016 the Third Order Regular of Saint Francis is present in Italy, Croatia, Spain, France, Germany, the United States, India, South Africa, Sri Lanka, Brazil, Paraguay, Mexico, Peru, Sweden, Bangladesh, and the Philippines. There are 208 convents. Members are assist in pastoral care within parishes, and are engaged with help for the needy, schools for the young, teaching, and missionary work. Members of the Third Order Regular wear a black habit rather than the brown habit worn by First Order congregations focused on poverty and the itinerant preaching of the Gospel.<ref name=Quinn/>
More than 448 congregations profess the "Rule and Life of the Brothers and Sisters of the Third Order Regular of St. Francis." There are 18 male congregations of Tertiary Franciscans, 370 congregations of Franciscan Sisters and 60 monasteries of cloistered nuns. The Third Order congregations of men and women number over 200,000 male and female religious.
A new Rule, written by friars and sisters of various congregations, was approved by [[Pope Paul VI]] in 1978. It is the current Rule followed by all congregations of the Third Order Regular, both men and women.

{{EngvarB|date=August 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2014}} {{Infobox person | name = Urvashi Butalia | image = UrvashiButalia.jpg | alt = | caption = Urvashi Butalia in 2011 | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth year and age|1952}} | birth_place = [[Ambala]], Haryana | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = | other_names = | occupation = Historian
co-founder [[Kali for Women]] (1984),
founder [[Zubaan Books]](2003) | known_for = |website={{URL|http://www.zubaanbooks.com/}} }} '''Urvashi Butalia''' (born 1952) is an Indian [[feminist]] and publisher. Along with [[Ritu Menon]], she co-founded [[Kali for Women]], India's first exclusively feminist publishing house, in 1984. In 2003, following the closure of Kali for Women, she founded [[Zubaan Books]].{{cite news|last=Daftuar|first=Swati|title=Identity matters|url=http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-features/tp-metroplus/article853524.ece|accessdate=26 April 2013|newspaper=The Hindu|date=28 October 2010}} ==Early life and education== Butalia was born in [[Ambala]], [[Haryana]], into a very rich, progressive and atheist family of [[Punjabi people|Punjabi]] heritage. She is the third of the four children of Joginder Singh Butalia and his wife Subhadra. Her mother, Subhadra Butalia, was a feminist who ran a counselling centre for women. Butalia has one [elder] sister, Bela, and two brothers, [[Pankaj Butalia|Pankaj]] and Rahul.[ [Pankaj Butalia]] is a left-wing documentary filmmaker best known for a documentary on the miserable conditions of widows living in [[Vrindavan]]. Butalia earned a BA in literature from [[Miranda House]], [[Delhi University]], in 1971, a [[master's degree]] in literature from Delhi University in 1973, and a master's in South Asian Studies from the [[University of London]] in 1977.{{cite web|title=Bio – Butalia|url=http://www.lettre-ulysses-award.org/jury06/bio_butalia.html|publisher=Lettre Ulysses Award for the Art of Reportage|accessdate=26 April 2013}} ==Career== Butalia started her career working with [[Oxford University Press]] in Delhi. She later worked for a year at their Oxford headquarters, before moving briefly to London-based [[Zed Books]] as an editor in 1982. She then returned to India and, along with [[Ritu Menon]], set up a feminist publishing house, [[Kali for Women]], in 1984, . Butalia's main areas of interest are [[Partition of India|partition]] and oral histories from a feminist and left-wing perspective. She has written on [[gender]], [[communalism]], [[fundamentalism]] and media. Her writings have appeared in several newspapers and magazines publications including ''[[The Guardian]]'', the ''[[New Internationalist]],'' ''[[The Statesman (India)|The Statesman]]'', ''[[The Times of India]],'' ''[[Outlook (magazine)|Outlook]]'' and ''[[India Today]]''. She has been a regular columnist for the left-wing ''[[Tehelka]]'' and for ''Indian Printer and publisher,'' a B2B publication dealing with the print and publishing industry. Butalia is a consultant for [[Oxfam]] India and she holds the position of Reader at the [[College of Vocational Studies]] at the University of Delhi. [[File:Urvabu.jpg|thumb|Urvashi Butalia in October 2016]] ===Kali for Women and Zubaan Books=== Kali for Women, India's first exclusively feminist publishing house, which Butalia co-founded with and Ritu Menon, was set up in 1984 as a trust to increase the body of knowledge on women in the Third World, to give voice to such knowledge as already exists, and to provide a forum for women writers, creative and academics.Puri, Jyoti, ''Woman, Body, Desire in Postcolonial India: Narratives of Gender and Sexuality'' (London: Routledge, 1999). In 2003, co-founders Urvashi Butalia and Ritu Menon parted ways due to unresolvable differences. Thereafter, Butalia started [[Zubaan Books]], which besides feminist books also published fiction, general interest books and children's titles, while Menon started Women Unlimited.{{cite web|first=Somak|last=Ghoshal| title = Urvashi Butalia: I want to prove that feminist publishing can survive commercially|publisher= Livemint| url =http://www.livemint.com/Companies/595QfElEltDLfuvgNqTiOI/Urvashi-Butalia--I-want-to-prove-that-feminist-publishing-c.html|date=14 June 2013|accessdate = 16 August 2013}} In 2011, Butalia and Menon were jointly conferred the [[Padma Shri]], India's fourth highest civilian award, by the [[Government of India]].{{cite press release|title=Padma Awards Announced|url=http://www.pib.nic.in/newsite/erelease.aspx?relid=69364|publisher=[[Ministry of Home Affairs (India)|Ministry of Home Affairs]] |date=25 January 2011|accessdate=16 August 2013}}{{cite news|title=President Confers Padma Awards|url=http://news.outlookindia.com/items.aspx?artid=716285|accessdate=26 April 2013|newspaper=Outlook India|date=24 March 2011}} ===''The Other Side of Silence''=== Apart from several newspaper articles and [[op-ed]] pieces dealing with feminist issues, Butalia has authored or co-authored seven books, listed below. Of these, ''The Other Side of Silence'' (1998) is being used as a text in some Indian universities. The book is the product of more than seventy interviews that Butalia conducted with survivors of the [[Partition of India|Partition]], and emphasises particularly the role of violence against women in the collective experience of the tragedy. Butalia points out that the Partition is, like the [[holocaust]], still very much a "living history", in the sense that many survivors are still around and can be interviewed. In contrast to the many projects that have undertaken to document the oral histories of the Holocaust, few comparable initiatives have been undertaken in India. This is one of them. == Activism == Butalia is an associate of the [[Women's Institute for Freedom of the Press]] (WIFP).{{Cite web|url=http://www.wifp.org/who-we-are/associates/|title=Associates {{!}} The Women’s Institute for Freedom of the Press|website=www.wifp.org|language=en-US|access-date=21 June 2017}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==Bibliography== * {{cite book|author1=Urvashi Butalia|author2=Ritu Menon|author3=Kali for Women |title=In Other Words: New Writing by Indian Women|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7cllAAAAMAAJ|year=1992|publisher=Kali for Women|isbn=978-81-85107-48-6}} * {{cite book|author1=Urvashi Butalia|author2=Ritu Menon|title=Making a Difference: Feminist Publishing in the South|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8mU8AQAAIAAJ|year=1995|publisher=Bellagio Pub. Network}} * {{cite book|author1=Tanika Sarkar|author2=Urvashi Butalia|title=Women and the Hindu Right: A Collection of Essays|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=CRIqAAAAYAAJ|year=1995|publisher=Kali For Women|isbn=978-81-85107-66-0}} * {{cite book|author1=Tanika Sarkar|author2=Urvashi Butalia|title=Women and Right Wing Movements: Indian Experiences|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=RjUqAAAAYAAJ|year=1995|publisher=Zed Books, London|isbn=978-1-85649-289-8}} * {{cite book|author=Urvashi Butalia |title=The Other Side of Silence: Voices from the Partition of India|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=JGklJI4eiNIC|year=1998|publisher=Penguin Books India|isbn=978-0-14-027171-3}} * {{cite book|author=Urvashi Butalia|title=Speaking Peace: Women's Voices from Kashmir|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=1WvaAAAAMAAJ|year=2002|publisher=Kali for Women|isbn=978-81-86706-43-5}} * {{cite book|author=Urvashi Butalia (ed.)|title=Inner Line: The Zubaan Book of Stories by Indian Women|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7nfNcEiSSMEC|year=2006|publisher=Zubaan|isbn=978-81-89013-77-6}} ==External links== {{commons category|Urvashi Butalia}} {{wikiquote}} * [http://www.zubaanbooks.com/ Zubaan Books website] * [http://www.lettre-ulysses-award.org/jury06/bio_butalia.html Biography as a member of the 2006 Lettre Ulysses Award jury] * [http://www.jfsonline.org/issue6/articles/butalia/ Interview] by Anupama Arora and Sandrine Sanos, ''Journal of Feminist Scholarship'' 6 (Spring 2014) {{distinguish|Wesley Walker}} {{pp-pc1|small=yes}} {{Infobox NFL biography | image = WesWelkerBroncos.jpg | image_size = 225 | alt = Wes Welker | caption = Welker with the Denver Broncos in 2013 | number = | current_team = Houston Texans | position = [[List of current National Football League staffs#AFC South#Houston Texans|Offensive assistant]] | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1981|5|1}} | birth_place = [[Oklahoma City, Oklahoma]] | death_date= | death_place= | height_ft=5 | height_in=9 | weight_lbs=185 | high_school= [[Heritage Hall School|Heritage Hall]]
(Oklahoma City, Oklahoma) | college= [[Texas Tech Red Raiders football|Texas Tech]] | undraftedyear=2004 | pastteams= * [[San Diego Chargers]] ({{NFL Year|2004}}) * [[Miami Dolphins]] ({{NFL Year|2004}}–{{NFL Year|2006}}) * [[New England Patriots]] ({{NFL Year|2007}}–{{NFL Year|2012}}) * [[Denver Broncos]] ({{NFL Year|2013}}–{{NFL Year|2014}}) * [[St. Louis Rams]] ({{NFL Year|2015}}) |pastcoaching= * [[Houston Texans]] ({{NFL Year|2017}}–present)
(Offensive assistant) | status = |highlights= * 5× [[Pro Bowl]] ([[2009 Pro Bowl|2008]]–[[2013 Pro Bowl|2012]]) * 2× First-team [[All-Pro]] ([[2009 All-Pro Team|2009]], [[2011 All-Pro Team|2011]]) * 2× Second-team [[All-Pro]] ([[2007 All-Pro Team|2007]], [[2008 All-Pro Team|2008]]) * 3× [[List of NFL annual receptions leaders|NFL receptions leader]] (2007, 2009, 2011) * NFL record [[99-yard pass play|99-yard reception]] (tied) * [[Mosi Tatupu Award]] (2003) * 2× First-team All-[[Big 12 Conference|Big 12]] (2002, 2003) | statlabel1 = [[Reception (American football)|Reception]]s | statvalue1 = 903 | statlabel2 = Receiving yards | statvalue2 = 9,924 | statlabel3 = Yards per reception | statvalue3 = 11.0 | statlabel4 = Receiving touchdowns | statvalue4 = 50 | nfl = WEL219433 }} '''Wesley Carter Welker''' (born May 1, 1981) is a former [[American football]] [[wide receiver]] who is currently an assistant coach for the [[Houston Texans]] of the [[National Football League]] (NFL). He played [[college football]] for the [[Texas Tech Red Raiders football|Texas Tech Red Raiders]] and was signed by the [[San Diego Chargers]] as an [[undrafted free agent]] in 2004. Welker went on to also play for the [[Miami Dolphins]], [[New England Patriots]], [[Denver Broncos]], and [[St. Louis Rams]]. Despite being undrafted, Welker had a successful career. Only one player in NFL history, [[Gale Sayers]], had more all-purpose yards in his first three NFL seasons than Welker did with the Dolphins; Welker holds the Dolphins' all-time records for total kickoff returns, kickoff return yardage, and total punt returns. Welker also holds the record for most receptions by any undrafted player in NFL history, passing [[Rod Smith (wide receiver)|Rod Smith]] in 2014.{{cite web|last1=Klis|first1=Mike|last2=Renck|first2=Troy|last3=Moss|first3=Irv|title=Broncos' Wes Welker humbly passes Rod Smith for "undrafted" record|url=http://www.denverpost.com/broncos/ci_26670469/broncos-wes-welker-humbly-passes-rod-smith-undrafted|work=Denver Post|accessdate=13 October 2014}} He retired with 16,797 all-purpose yards. As a Patriot, Welker led the league in receptions in [[2007 NFL season|2007]], [[2009 NFL season|2009]], and [[2011 NFL season|2011]]. Welker holds the four highest single-season reception totals in Patriots' history, as well as four of the top 10 receiving yardage totals, including the franchise record. He also holds the franchise records for most receptions in a single game, most receiving yards in a single game, longest reception, and career receptions.{{cite web|url=http://www.patriots.com/team/index.cfm?ac=playerbio&bio=31608|title=Wes Welker – Official New England Patriots Biography|work=[[New England Patriots]]|accessdate=2009-12-29|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091217032710/http://www.patriots.com/team/index.cfm?ac=playerbio&bio=31608|archivedate=2009-12-17|df=}} Welker, who had three consecutive 110-reception seasons (and has five total), is the first receiver in NFL history with at least three 110-reception seasons, and the first with five 100-reception seasons. Welker was selected to the [[Pro Bowl]], the All-Pro Team, or both, in every season of his Patriots career. ==Early years== Welker started his football career at [[Heritage Hall School|Heritage Hall High School]] in Oklahoma City.{{Cite news |url=http://www.tulsaworld.com/sportsextra/okpreps/st-louis-rams-sign-former-heritage-hall-receiver-wes-welker/article_241314c2-d068-5e74-8cd5-6035abb31b94.html |title=St. Louis Rams sign former Heritage Hall receiver Wes Welker |work=Tulsa World |access-date=2018-03-15 |language=en}} In his junior year, he helped lead the Chargers to the 2A State Football championship over Tishomingo High School. In that game, Welker had three touchdowns, over 200 all-purpose yards, a 47-yard field goal, and an interception.{{cite web|url=http://www.signonsandiego.com/sports/nfl/20080202-0123-fbn-superbowl-welker.html|title=Back in Oklahoma, story of Welker's rise to glory is often told|publisher=Signonsandiego.com|date=2008-02-02|accessdate=2012-01-07}} Also, in 1999, he was named ''[[The Daily Oklahoman]]'' All-State Player of the Year, as well as Oklahoma State Player of the Year by ''[[USA Today]]''. Welker played in the 2000 [[Oil Bowl (high school)|Oil Bowl]], scoring a 40-yard field goal for the Oklahoma team. Out of high school, Welker was not recruited heavily, as he was considered to be too small to play at the college level. However, after a recruit at Texas Tech backed out of his scholarship, it was offered to Welker.{{cite web|url=http://media.www.dailytoreador.com/media/storage/paper870/news/2007/03/26/Sports/Greatest.Tech.Athelete.Poll.Wes.Welker.And.Zach.Thomas.Profiles-2790280.shtml?reffeature=htmlemailedition |title=Greatest Tech athlete poll: Wes Welker and Zach Thomas profiles |work=[[The Daily Toreador]] |date=March 26, 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070929084135/http://media.www.dailytoreador.com/media/storage/paper870/news/2007/03/26/Sports/Greatest.Tech.Athelete.Poll.Wes.Welker.And.Zach.Thomas.Profiles-2790280.shtml?reffeature=htmlemailedition |archivedate=September 29, 2007 }} Said Welker of the experience:
"I was thinking I'd get a scholarship somewhere. When it didn't happen when it was supposed to, on signing day, I was pretty hurt by it. … In the end, I don't think I could've picked a better school than Texas Tech."{{cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/sports/football/nfl/patriots/2008-01-28-welker-cover_N.htm|title=Patriots' Welker goes from bit player to center stage|work=[[USA Today]]|date=January 28, 2008 | first=Jarrett | last=Bell}}
At Heritage Hall, Welker was a prolific contributor on offense, defense, and special teams. As a running back, he scored 80 touchdowns (53 rushing and 27 receiving). As a defensive back, he had 190 tackles, 22 interceptions (three of which he returned for touchdowns), and nine fumble recoveries. As a punt returner, he scored seven touchdowns. As a kicker, he kicked 35 field goals and 165 extra points. His longest field goal was 58 yards. ==College career== While attending [[Texas Tech University]], Welker played for the [[Texas Tech Red Raiders football|Texas Tech Red Raiders]].{{Cite web |url=https://www.sports-reference.com/cfb/players/wes-welker-1.html |title=Wes Welker College Stats |website=College Football at Sports-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-03-15}} His last-minute signing proved to be very beneficial for the Red Raider football team. Based on a highlight reel from high school, Welker earned the nickname "The Natural", given to him by his recruiter, and then running backs coach at Texas Tech, [[Art Briles]], before his freshman year for his versatility and big-game performances.{{cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/sports/football/nfl/patriots/2007-11-23-sw-wes-welker_N.htm|title=Early frustration couldn't stop Welker's emergence|work=[[USA Today]]|date=November 23, 2007 | first=Tom | last=Pedulla}}{{cite web|url=http://www.eagletribune.com/pusports/local_story_322093916?keyword=secondarystory+page=0|title=The Natural: Welker goes from unknown to irreplaceable|publisher=[[The Eagle-Tribune]]|date=November 18, 2007|access-date=2007-11-26|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081209001000/http://www.eagletribune.com/pusports/local_story_322093916?keyword=secondarystory+page=0|archive-date=2008-12-09|dead-url=yes|df=}} As a freshman, he had 26 receptions for 334 yards to go along with a 42-yard rushing touchdown.{{Cite web |url=https://www.sports-reference.com/cfb/players/wes-welker-1/gamelog/2000/ |title=Wes Welker 2000 Game Log |website=College Football at Sports-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-03-15}} As a sophomore, he had 50 receptions for 582 yards and two touchdowns.{{Cite web |url=https://www.sports-reference.com/cfb/players/wes-welker-1/gamelog/2001/ |title=Wes Welker 2001 Game Log |website=College Football at Sports-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-03-15}} As a junior, he had 86 receptions for 1,054 yards and seven touchdowns.{{Cite web |url=https://www.sports-reference.com/cfb/players/wes-welker-1/gamelog/2002/ |title=Wes Welker 2002 Game Log |website=College Football at Sports-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-03-15}} As a senior, he had 97 receptions for 1,099 yards and nine touchdowns to go along with a four-yard rushing touchdown.{{Cite web |url=https://www.sports-reference.com/cfb/players/wes-welker-1/gamelog/2003/ |title=Wes Welker 2003 Game Log |website=College Football at Sports-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-03-15}} Over his four-year career, he had 259 receptions for 3,019 yards and 21 [[touchdown]]s and 79 rushes for 456 yards and two touchdowns. He also scored eight touchdowns returning punts in his career, which earns him a second place tie for the [[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]] record, behind [[Dante Pettis]] who has 9. In 2003, Welker won the [[Mosi Tatupu Award]], given annually to the best special teams player in college football. Welker was also named to the ''[[Sports Illustrated]]'' All-Decade Team as a punt returner.{{Citation needed|date=September 2016}} After his senior season at Texas Tech, Welker was not invited to the [[NFL Scouting Combine]].{{cite web|title=Combine & Wes Welker|url=http://www.boston.com/sports/football/patriots/reiss_pieces/2009/02/combine_wes_wel.html|accessdate=February 19, 2009 }} ===Collegiate statistics=== {| class="wikitable" ! Year ! School ! Class ! Pos ! G ! Rec ! Yds ! Avg ! TD ! Rush ! Yds ! Avg ! TD |- | [[2000 NCAA Division I-A football season|2000]] | [[2000 Texas Tech Red Raiders football team|Texas Tech]] | Freshman | RB | 12 | 26 | 334 | 12.8 | 0 | 6 | 72 | 12.0 | 1 |- | [[2001 NCAA Division I-A football season|2001]] | [[2001 Texas Tech Red Raiders football team|Texas Tech]] | Sophomore | WR | 11 | 50 | 582 | 11.6 | 5 | 15 | 97 | 6.5 | 0 |- | [[2002 NCAA Division I-A football season|2002]] | [[2002 Texas Tech Red Raiders football team|Texas Tech]] | Junior | WR | 14 | 86 | 1,054 | 12.3 | 7 | 31 | 244 | 7.9 | 0 |- | [[2003 NCAA Division I-A football season|2003]] | [[2003 Texas Tech Red Raiders football team|Texas Tech]] | Senior | WR | 13 | 97 | 1,099 | 11.3 | 9 | 27 | 146 | 5.4 | 1 |- | style="font-weight: bold;" | Career | style="font-weight: bold;" | | style="font-weight: bold;" | | style="font-weight: bold;" | | style="font-weight: bold;" | 50 | style="font-weight: bold;" | 259 | style="font-weight: bold;" | 3,069 | style="font-weight: bold;" | 11.8 | style="font-weight: bold;" | 21 | style="font-weight: bold;" | 79 | style="font-weight: bold;" | 559 | style="font-weight: bold;" | 7.1 | style="font-weight: bold;" | 2 |} ==Professional playing career== ===Pre-draft=== {{nfl predraft | height ft = 5 | height in = 8¾ | weight = 186 | dash = 4.65 | ten split = | twenty split = | shuttle = 4.01 | cone drill = 7.09 | vertical = 30 | broad ft = 9 | broad in = 5 | bench = 12 | wonderlic = 30 | arm span = | hand span = | note = All values from Texas Tech Pro Day{{cite web|url=http://draftscout.com/ratings/dsprofile.php?pyid=1982&draftyear=2004&genpos=WR|title=Wes Welker - Texas Tech, WR : 2004 NFL Draft Scout Player Profile|author=|date=|website=draftscout.com}} }} ===San Diego Chargers (2004)=== Welker, who went undrafted during the [[2004 NFL Draft]], signed as an [[undrafted free agent]] with the [[San Diego Chargers]]. Welker made the Chargers out of training camp, but was released after the first game of the season when the Chargers claimed safety [[Clinton Hart]] off waivers. [[Head coach]] [[Marty Schottenheimer]] later acknowledged that in terms of roster cuts, releasing Welker was the "biggest mistake [he] ever made".Howe, Jeff. (2012-01-03) [http://www.nesn.com/2012/01/wes-welker-has-spent-football-life-proving-doubters-wrong-from-college-coaches-to-nfl-executives.html Wes Welker Has Spent Football Life Proving Doubters Wrong, From College Coaches to NFL Executives | New England Patriots]. NESN.com. Retrieved on 2013-01-21. ===Miami Dolphins (2004–2006)=== ====2004 season==== {{See also|2004 Miami Dolphins season}} After the Chargers released Welker, he passed through waivers. Although the Chargers offered him a slot on their [[practice squad]], Welker chose to sign with the [[Miami Dolphins]] instead, where he was mostly used on [[special teams]]. Playing against the [[New England Patriots]] on October 10, 2004, Welker became the second player in NFL history to return a kickoff and a punt, kick an extra point and a [[Field goal (football)|field goal]], and make a [[Tackle (football move)|tackle]] in a single game.{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/200410100nwe.htm |title=Miami Dolphins at New England Patriots - October 10th, 2004 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-03-15}} On December 20, Welker had a 71-yard punt return to set up Miami's first touchdown in a 29–28 victory over the Patriots on ''[[Monday Night Football]]''.{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/200412200mia.htm |title=New England Patriots at Miami Dolphins - December 20th, 2004 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-03-15}} In the regular season finale against the Baltimore Ravens, he had 95-yard kickoff return touchdown in the 30–23 loss.{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/200501020rav.htm |title=Miami Dolphins at Baltimore Ravens - January 2nd, 2005 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-03-15}} Overall, he finished the 2004 season with 61 kick returns for 1,415 net yards and a touchdown to go along with 43 punt returns for 464 net yards.{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/players/W/WelkWe00/gamelog/2004/ |title=Wes Welker 2004 Game Log |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-03-15}} ====2005 season==== {{See also|2005 Miami Dolphins season}} During training camp at the beginning of the [[2005 NFL season|2005 season]], Welker was promoted to the third [[wide receiver]] spot after [[Chris Chambers]] and [[Marty Booker]].{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/teams/mia/2005.htm |title=2005 Miami Dolphins Statistics & Players |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-03-15}} He finished the 2005 season with 29 receptions for 434 yards, but did not score a touchdown. He also had 43 punt returns for 390 yards, a 9.1-yard average (11th in the NFL), and 61 kickoff returns for 1,379 yards, a 22.6-yard average (20th in the NFL).{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/players/W/WelkWe00/gamelog/2005/ |title=Wes Welker 2005 Game Log |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2017-12-16}}{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/years/2005/returns.htm |title=2005 NFL Kick & Punt Returns |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2017-12-16}} ====2006 season==== {{See also|2006 Miami Dolphins season}} After rumors that he would be cut during the preseason, Welker started off being the lone bright spot in the struggling Dolphins' offense. Through five games, he netted a team-high 29 catches and team-high 299 yards. On October 8, 2006, he was a huge target for back-up [[quarterback]] [[Joey Harrington]], recording a then career-high nine catches for 77 yards in a 20–10 loss to the Patriots. For [[2006 Miami Dolphins season|the season]], he had a team-best 67 receptions for 687 yards and one touchdown. He returned 48 kickoffs for 1,048 yards (22.2 average) and 41 punts for 378 yards (9.2 average).{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/teams/mia/2006.htm |title=2006 Miami Dolphins Statistics & Players |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-03-15}}{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/players/W/WelkWe00/gamelog/2006/ |title=Wes Welker 2006 Game Log |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-03-15}} ===New England Patriots (2007–2012)=== ====Trade to New England==== [[Image:patriotsgiants 046.jpg|thumb|Welker (right) being interviewed after the final game of the undefeated [[2007 New England Patriots season|2007 Patriots]] regular season]] On March 1, 2007, the Dolphins offered Welker, a restricted free agent, a second-round tender of $1.35 million for a one-year contract. News reports indicated the New England Patriots, who were interested in Welker, had originally considered signing him to an offer sheet (Miami would have had seven days to match the offer); according to ''[[The Boston Globe]]'', that sheet would have contained a [[poison pill#Sports|poison pill]] provision that would have made the offer difficult for the Dolphins to match.{{cite web|url=http://www.boston.com/sports/football/patriots/articles/2007/10/17/patriots_pounced_fast_to_grab_welker|title=How Patriots grabbed wide receiver Wes Welker from Dolphins|work=[[The Boston Globe]]|first=Mike|last=Reiss|date=2007-10-17|accessdate=2010-01-11}} Ultimately, however, the Patriots decided not to use such an offer and traded their 2007 second-round draft pick and a seventh-round draft pick to the Dolphins for Welker. ====2007 season==== {{See also|2007 New England Patriots season}} Welker's first season as a Patriot eclipsed his 2006 season as a Dolphin; he bettered his totals for receptions, touchdowns, and yardage in his first ten games. In Week 1, he caught the first of the Patriots' record 75 touchdowns, equaling the one receiving touchdown he had scored in his three seasons with the Dolphins. He set career highs for single-game yardage three times in 2007: in the Patriots' Week 6 win against the [[2007 Dallas Cowboys season|Dallas Cowboys]], Welker had 11 catches for 124 yards and two touchdowns (all career bests);{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/200710140dal.htm |title=New England Patriots at Dallas Cowboys - October 14th, 2007 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-03-15}} the next week, against the [[2007 Miami Dolphins season|Dolphins]], he had nine catches for 138 yards and two more touchdowns (the most receiving yards of any NFL player that week);{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/200710210mia.htm |title=New England Patriots at Miami Dolphins - October 21st, 2007 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-03-15}} and in Week 12, against the [[2007 Philadelphia Eagles season|Philadelphia Eagles]], he had 13 receptions for 149 yards.{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/200711250nwe.htm |title=Philadelphia Eagles at New England Patriots - November 25th, 2007 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-03-15}} In Week 15, against the [[2007 New York Jets season|New York Jets]], Welker reached 1,000 receiving yards for the first time in his career;{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/200712160nwe.htm |title=New York Jets at New England Patriots - December 16th, 2007 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-03-15}} in Week 16, against the Dolphins, he recorded his 101st reception of the season, tying the Patriots franchise record set by [[Troy Brown]] in [[2001 NFL season|2001]].{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/200712230nwe.htm |title=Miami Dolphins at New England Patriots - December 23rd, 2007 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-03-15}}{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/teams/nwe/single-season-receiving.htm |title=New England Patriots Single-Season Receiving Leaders |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-03-15}} In Week 17, against the [[2007 New York Giants season|Giants]], he caught 11 more passes, setting the Patriots franchise record for catches with 112, and tying [[Cincinnati Bengals|Bengals]] receiver [[T. J. Houshmandzadeh]] for most receptions in the [[2007 NFL season]].{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/200712290nyg.htm |title=New England Patriots at New York Giants - December 29th, 2007 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-03-15}}{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/years/2007/receiving.htm |title=2007 NFL Receiving |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-03-15}} He also set an NFL record for most catches in a first season with a new team. Welker, who finished the season with 1,175 yards and eight touchdowns, received one vote for [[National Football League Offensive Player of the Year Award|NFL Offensive Player of the Year]], an award won by his quarterback, [[Tom Brady]], and was voted to his first AP All-Pro Team (second team).{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/players/W/WelkWe00/gamelog/2007/ |title=Wes Welker 2007 Game Log |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-03-15}} In his first two postseason games, Welker had 16 receptions for 110 yards and two touchdowns.{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/200801120nwe.htm |title=Divisional Round - Jacksonville Jaguars at New England Patriots - January 12th, 2008 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-03-15}}{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/200801200nwe.htm |title=AFC Championship - San Diego Chargers at New England Patriots - January 20th, 2008 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-03-15}} He tied the then Super Bowl record of 11 receptions in a single game in the Patriots' 17–14 loss to the Giants in [[Super Bowl XLII]].{{cite news|url=http://www.sportingnews.com/yourturn/viewtopic.php?t=346942|title=Welker ties Super Bowl record with 11 catches|agency=Associated Press|publisher=[[Sporting News]]|date=2008-02-04|accessdate=2010-01-11|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090104124704/http://www.sportingnews.com/yourturn/viewtopic.php?t=346942|archivedate=2009-01-04|df=}}{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/200802030nwe.htm |title=Super Bowl XLII - New York Giants vs. New England Patriots - February 3rd, 2008 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-03-15}} ====2008 season==== {{See also|2008 New England Patriots season}} Despite the season-ending injury to quarterback [[Tom Brady]] in Week 1, he continued to amass receptions at the same pace through the first half of the season with [[Matt Cassel]]: through eight games, he had 56 receptions, but only one touchdown reception. He had six or more receptions in each of the Patriots' first 11 games, breaking [[Jimmy Smith (wide receiver)|Jimmy Smith]]'s mark of eight games at the start of the [[Jacksonville Jaguars]]' [[2001 Jacksonville Jaguars season|2001 season]].{{cite web|url=http://www.patriots.com/news/index.cfm?ac=latestnewsdetail&pid=35042&pcid=47|title=Patriots vs. Bills game notes|work=[[New England Patriots]]|date=2008-11-09|accessdate=2010-01-11}}{{dead link|date=August 2017 |bot=Red Director |fix-attempted=yes }} Welker had what was, at the time, the longest pass play of his NFL career in the Patriots' 48–28 victory over the Miami Dolphins in Week 12: on 2nd-and-8 from their own 15, Welker caught a 5-yard pass from [[Matt Cassel]], before eluding a pair of defenders tip-toeing and running down the left sideline to the Miami 21, for a total of 64 yards, 59 yards after the catch.{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/200811230mia.htm |title=New England Patriots at Miami Dolphins - November 23rd, 2008 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-03-15}} Welker broke the 1,000-yard mark for the second consecutive season in Week 14 against the [[Seattle Seahawks]], catching 12 passes for 134 yards, and catching a pass on the Patriots' two-point conversion.{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/200812070sea.htm |title=New England Patriots at Seattle Seahawks - December 7th, 2008 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-03-15}} He finished the season with a league-leading 96 receptions, for 1,002 yards (ninth in the NFL, third in the AFC).{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/players/W/WelkWe00/gamelog/2008/ |title=Wes Welker 2008 Game Log |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-03-15}}{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/years/2008/receiving.htm |title=2008 NFL Receiving |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-03-15}} Against the [[Oakland Raiders]] one week later, Welker became the first player in Patriots history, and the eighth in NFL history, to have back-to-back 100-reception seasons; the previous player to do it was his teammate [[Randy Moss]], while he was a [[Minnesota Vikings|Viking]], in [[2002 NFL season|2002]] and [[2003 NFL season|2003]], and [[Brandon Marshall]] accomplished the feat in the same seasons as Welker.{{cite web|url=http://www.boston.com/sports/football/patriots/reiss_pieces/2008/12/some_firsthalf.html|title=Some first-half notes|work=Boston.com Reiss' Pieces|first=Gary|last=Dzen|date=2008-12-14|accessdate=2010-01-11}} Welker was fined $10,000 by the NFL for celebrating a December 21 touchdown against the [[Arizona Cardinals]] by lying down in the snow by the [[endzone]] and using his body to make a [[snow angel]], violating a recent [[National Football League|NFL]] rule change making going to ground after a touchdown unsportsmanlike conduct.{{cite web|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/news/story?id=3792441|title=Pats' Welker fined for TD antic|publisher=[[ESPN]]|date=2008-12-24|accessdate=2009-01-11}} Welker was selected to attend the [[2009 Pro Bowl]] as a reserve,{{cite web|url=http://www.patriots.com/search/index.cfm?ac=searchdetail&pid=35778&pcid=47&rss=1|title=Welker and Gostkowski selected to Pro Bowl squad|work=[[New England Patriots]]|date=2008-12-16|accessdate=2010-01-11}}{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} and was again named to the AP All-Pro Second Team.{{cite web|url=http://www.boston.com/sports/football/patriots/articles/2009/01/10/gostkowski_named_all_pro/|title=Gostkowski named All-Pro|work=[[The Boston Globe]]|first=Christopher L.|last=Gasper|date=2009-01-10|accessdate=2009-05-21}} ====2009 season==== {{See also|2009 New England Patriots season}} Welker was sidelined in Weeks 2 and 3 (against the [[New York Jets]] and [[Atlanta Falcons]], respectively) with a knee injury; rookie [[wide receiver]] [[Julian Edelman]] took his place in the lineup. In the Week 6 game against the [[Tennessee Titans]] on October 18, Welker caught 10 passes for 150 yards, a new career high (at the time), and two touchdowns.{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/200910180nwe.htm |title=Tennessee Titans at New England Patriots - October 18th, 2009 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-03-15}} The second of Welker's touchdowns was Tom Brady's NFL record fifth touchdown in a single quarter. Welker set career marks again in the Patriots' Week 11 rematch against the Jets: targeted 17 times, he caught 15 passes — at the time the highest single-game total for any player in the NFL in 2009 — for 192 yards, and added 11 rushing yards on a reverse.{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/200911220nwe.htm |title=New York Jets at New England Patriots - November 22nd, 2009 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-03-15}} In Week 13 against the Dolphins, Welker recorded 167 receiving yards to eclipse the 1,000-yard mark for the third straight season. Against the [[Miami Dolphins]] in Week 13, Welker tallied 167 yards on 10 catches, including a season long 58-yard reception over the middle.{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/200912060mia.htm |title=New England Patriots at Miami Dolphins - December 6th, 2009 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-03-15}} In the Patriots' Week 14 win at home against the [[Carolina Panthers]], Welker caught 10 passes (out of 19 total completions for Brady) for 105 yards.{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/200912130nwe.htm |title=Carolina Panthers at New England Patriots - December 13th, 2009 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-03-15}} This gave him 105 receptions in just 11 games and Welker led the NFL in receptions at that point. The performance also made Welker the fourth receiver in NFL history (after [[Jerry Rice]], [[Herman Moore]], and [[Marvin Harrison]], and tied with [[Brandon Marshall]] who did it in the same seasons as Welker) to catch 100 passes in three consecutive seasons. In Week 16, Welker caught 13 passes, giving him 7 games with double digit receptions.{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/200912270nwe.htm |title=Jacksonville Jaguars at New England Patriots - December 27th, 2009 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-03-15}} This gave him the record for most double digit reception games in a single season, passing [[Marvin Harrison]]. He accomplished this despite missing two games earlier in the season. [[Image:Wes Welker 1.JPG|thumb|alt=|Wes Welker before a game against the [[Cincinnati Bengals]] on September 12, 2010.]] In a Week 17 loss to the [[Houston Texans]], Welker suffered a knee injury after getting hit by [[Bernard Pollard]] in the first quarter while running upfield to make his only reception of the game.{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/201001030htx.htm |title=New England Patriots at Houston Texans - January 3rd, 2010 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-03-15}} He suffered a torn [[Medial collateral ligament|MCL]] and [[Anterior cruciate ligament|ACL]] in his left knee and was placed on [[injured reserve]] on January 6, 2010.{{cite web|url=http://www.boston.com/sports/football/patriots/articles/2010/01/04/a_mess_in_texas/|title=A mess in Texas|work=[[The Boston Globe]]|first=Adam|last=Kilgore|date=2010-01-04|accessdate=2010-01-04}} Welker finished the season with a league-high 123 receptions (the second-highest total in NFL history) and finished second in yardage, behind Houston's [[Andre Johnson]].{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/leaders/rec_single_season.htm |title=NFL Receptions Single-Season Leaders |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-03-15}}{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/years/2009/receiving.htm |title=2009 NFL Receiving |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-03-15}} He was also selected to represent the AFC in the [[2010 Pro Bowl|Pro Bowl]] for the second consecutive year, and, for the first time in his career, was named to the [[All-Pro]] First Team. Because of the knee injury he could not play in the Pro Bowl, and was replaced on the Pro Bowl roster by teammate [[Randy Moss]]. ====2010 season==== {{See also|2010 New England Patriots season}} Welker rehabilitated his knee during the 2010 offseason with the goal of being ready for the 2010 season opener,{{cite web|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/boston/nfl/news/story?id=5565716|title=Welker returns to action with two TDs|work=ESPNBoston.com|first=David|last=Lefort|date=2010-09-13|accessdate=2010-09-13}} while many analysts expected that he would start the season on the [[Physically Unable to Perform]] list, and some even speculated that he would miss the entire 2010 season.{{cite web|url=http://blog.masslive.com/patriots/2010/01/wes_welker_injury_out_for_2010_season.html|title=Boomer Esiason: Wes Welker could miss entire 2010 season with ACL, MCL injuries|work=[[The Republican (Springfield)|The Republican]]|first=Frank|last=Gallant|date=2010-01-04|accessdate=2010-09-13}} Nonetheless, Welker played in the Patriots' Week 1 game against the [[Cincinnati Bengals]], and led all Patriots receivers with 8 catches for 64 yards and two touchdowns; those catches included Brady's first pass attempt of the season and his first touchdown pass.{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/201009120nwe.htm |title=Cincinnati Bengals at New England Patriots - September 12th, 2010 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-03-15}} In the Patriots' Week 9 loss to the [[Cleveland Browns]], after an injury to kicker [[Stephen Gostkowski]], Welker was asked to kick an [[extra point]] for the first time since he did so in 2004 against the Patriots; he converted the attempt.{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/201011070cle.htm |title=New England Patriots at Cleveland Browns - November 7th, 2010 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-03-15}} Welker, who had two touchdown catches in the Patriots' 45–24 win over the [[Detroit Lions]] on [[NFL on Thanksgiving Day|Thanksgiving]], finished the 2010 season with 86 receptions for 848 yards and seven touchdowns in 15 games played (11 starts).{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/201011250det.htm |title=New England Patriots at Detroit Lions - November 25th, 2010 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-03-15}}{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/players/W/WelkWe00/gamelog/2010/ |title=Wes Welker 2010 Game Log |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-03-15}} He was named to the [[2011 Pro Bowl]] as an injury replacement to Texans wide receiver [[Andre Johnson]]. In the playoff loss to the [[New York Jets]], Welker was benched for the teams' first offensive series for making a series of foot references in a press conference that took shots at a [[foot fetish]] of Jets' coach [[Rex Ryan]].Cole, Mike. (2011-01-16) [http://www.nesn.com/2011/01/wes-welker-benched-for-start-of-patriots-jets-divisional-round-game.html Wes Welker Benched for Start of Patriots-Jets Divisional Round Game | Headlines]. NESN.com. Retrieved on 2013-01-21. ====2011 season==== {{See also|2011 New England Patriots season}} In the Patriots' 38–24 Week 1 win over the [[Miami Dolphins]], Welker caught a [[99-yard pass play|99-yard pass]] from Tom Brady. Tying the NFL record for longest play from scrimmage, it was the 12th such play in NFL history, and the first for the Patriots. The play accounted for the majority of Welker's yards in an 8-catch effort for 160 yards and two touchdowns.{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/201109120mia.htm |title=New England Patriots at Miami Dolphins - September 12th, 2011 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-03-15}} In Week 3, in the Patriots' 34–31 loss to the [[Buffalo Bills]], Welker had 16 receptions for 217 yards and two touchdowns. {{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/201109250buf.htm |title=New England Patriots at Buffalo Bills - September 25th, 2011 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-03-15}}In so doing, he tied wide receiver [[Troy Brown]]'s franchise record of 16 receptions in a single game and broke [[Terry Glenn]]'s franchise record of 214 yards, set in 1999. The game also marked Welker's 64th consecutive regular-season game with a reception (i.e., in every game he has played as a Patriot), breaking tight end [[Ben Coates]]'s record of 63 games (set 1992 to 1996).[http://boston.cbslocal.com/2011/09/25/patriots-welker-sets-franchise-record/ Patriots Welker Sets New Franchise Records « CBS Boston]. Boston.cbslocal.com (2011-09-25). Retrieved on 2013-01-21. It was Welker's second game with at least 15 receptions, a feat equaled only by [[Brandon Marshall]] with the [[Denver Broncos]]. In Week 5, in the Patriots' win over the Jets, Welker caught five passes for 124 yards, including a 73-yard catch-and-run in which Welker beat [[Eric Smith (American football)|Eric Smith]] and was chased down by [[Darrelle Revis]] at the 8-yard line.{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/201110090nwe.htm |title=New York Jets at New England Patriots - October 9th, 2011 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-03-15}} In Week 14, against the [[Washington Redskins]], Welker recorded his 100th reception of the season, giving him four seasons with at least 100 receptions, tying the NFL record shared by [[Marvin Harrison]] and [[Jerry Rice]]. He also set a personal best with his ninth receiving touchdown.{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/201112110was.htm |title=New England Patriots at Washington Redskins - December 11th, 2011 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-03-15}} In the Patriots' Week 16 rematch against the Dolphins, Welker had 12 receptions for 138 yards, bringing him to a franchise-record 1,518 receiving yards, besting Randy Moss' 2007 record of 1,493 yards.{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/201112240nwe.htm |title=Miami Dolphins at New England Patriots - December 24th, 2011 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-03-15}} Through 15 games, Welker led the NFL in receptions, receiving yards, yards per game, and receptions for first downs, and ranked in the top five in receiving touchdowns and receptions of 20 yards or more. He finished the season with 122 receptions (tied for fourth-highest total in NFL history), 1,569 receiving yards and 98.5 yards per game (both second to [[Calvin Johnson]]), and 77 receptions for first down (tied with Johnson for the NFL lead). He also had a career-high 9 touchdown receptions. {{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/years/2011/receiving.htm |title=2011 NFL Receiving |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-03-15}}The Patriots reached [[Super Bowl XLVI]] where they would face the [[New York Giants]] in a rematch of [[Super Bowl XLII]]. In the Super Bowl, Welker had 7 catches for 60 yards, but the Patriots would lose to the Giants again, this time by a score of 21–17.{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/201202050nwe.htm |title=Super Bowl XLVI - New York Giants vs. New England Patriots - February 5th, 2012 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2017-12-06}} ====2012 season==== {{See also|2012 New England Patriots season}} In the Patriots' Week 1 win over the [[Tennessee Titans]], with three receptions for 14 yards, Welker tied former Patriots receiver [[Troy Brown]]'s franchise record for receptions; he took sole possession of the franchise record for receptions a week later against the [[Arizona Cardinals]] with five receptions for 95 yards.{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/201209090oti.htm |title=New England Patriots at Tennessee Titans - September 9th, 2012 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-03-15}}{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/201209160nwe.htm |title=Arizona Cardinals at New England Patriots - September 16th, 2012 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-03-15}} In Week 3, against the Baltimore Ravens, he had eight receptions for 142 yards.{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/201209230rav.htm |title=New England Patriots at Baltimore Ravens - September 23rd, 2012 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-03-15}} On October 14, in a 24–23 loss to the Seattle Seahawks, he had 10 receptions for 138 yards and a touchdown.{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/201210140sea.htm |title=New England Patriots at Seattle Seahawks - October 14th, 2012 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-03-15}} During the Week 13 game against the [[Miami Dolphins]], Welker, with, 12 receptions, set the NFL record for the most games with 10 or more receptions, tying him with [[San Francisco 49ers|49ers]] legend and Hall of Famer [[Jerry Rice]].{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/201212020mia.htm |title=New England Patriots at Miami Dolphins - December 2nd, 2012 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-03-15}} It was his 17th game completing this task. He also set the NFL record for most games with 10 or more catches and 100 or more yards. With his 16th such performance, he moved ahead of Jerry Rice and [[Andre Johnson]]. Overall, he finished the 2012 season with 118 receptions for 1,354 receiving yards and six touchdowns.{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/players/W/WelkWe00/gamelog/2012/ |title=Wes Welker 2012 Game Log |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-03-15}} He ended the season tied with [[Chicago Bears]] receiver [[Brandon Marshall]] for second in receptions with 118, behind [[Detroit Lions|Detroit]]'s [[Calvin Johnson]].{{cite web|last=Mayer|first=Larry|url=http://www.chicagobears.com/news/article-1/Reviewing-Bears-season-by-the-numbers/527155e6-2790-458c-a3df-c26aaf2c136c|title=Reviewing Bears season by the numbers|publisher=[[Chicago Bears]]|date=2013-01-07|accessdate=2013-01-07|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141006093201/http://www.chicagobears.com/news/article-1/Reviewing-Bears-season-by-the-numbers/527155e6-2790-458c-a3df-c26aaf2c136c|archive-date=2014-10-06|dead-url=yes|df=}}{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/years/2012/receiving.htm |title=2012 NFL Receiving |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-03-15}} ====Patriots career summary==== After joining the Patriots, Welker caught more passes than any player in the league in the period between 2007-2012, and ranks in the top five in yardage. Welker reached 500 receptions with the Patriots in just 70 games, an NFL record.[https://archive.is/20120724023855/http://www.csnwashington.com/blog/nationals-talk/post/Washington-wary-of-Welker?blockID=608930&feedID=635 Washington wary of Welker]. CSN Washington (2011-12-09). Retrieved on 2013-01-21. Welker holds the franchise record for consecutive games with receptions, having caught a pass in every game (regular season and postseason) he has played as a Patriot. As of Week 2 of the 2012 regular season, Welker also holds the all-time Patriots franchise record for receptions, breaking in just 79 games the record of [[Troy Brown]] who played more than twice as many games as a Patriot (192 regular-season games). Welker ranks third in receiving yards behind Brown and [[Stanley Morgan]]. ===Denver Broncos (2013–2014)=== On March 13, 2013, Welker signed a two-year, $12 million contract with the [[Denver Broncos]].{{cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/new-york/nfl/story/_/id/9048556/wes-welker-agrees-terms-denver-broncos|title=Wes Welker agrees with Broncos|publisher=[[ESPN]]|date=2013-03-13|accessdate=2013-03-13}} Welker's signing with Denver was a result of Welker and the New England Patriots being unable to agree to a contract.{{cite web|url=http://www.nfl.com/news/story/0ap1000000150677/article/patriots-botch-wes-welker-situation-titans-crushing-free-agency|title=Patriots botch Wes Welker situation; Titans crushing free agency|publisher=}} ====2013 season==== {{See also|2013 Denver Broncos season}} In his debut with the Broncos, Welker had nine receptions for 67 yards and two touchdowns against the [[Baltimore Ravens]].{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/201309050den.htm |title=Baltimore Ravens at Denver Broncos - September 5th, 2013 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-03-15}} Through Week 11, he had 50 receptions for 555 yards and nine touchdowns. By Week 11, Welker had more touchdowns than he had the entire previous season with [[New England Patriots|New England]] (six), and as many as he had in any season with the Patriots (nine). He caught a touchdown pass in 8 of the first 10 games of the 2013 season.{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/players/W/WelkWe00/gamelog/2013/ |title=Wes Welker 2013 Game Log |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-03-15}} In a game against the [[Tennessee Titans]], Welker took a hit to the head on a play across the middle late in the second quarter, and his neck bent awkwardly on the play. Welker previously suffered a concussion in Week 11 against the [[Kansas City Chiefs]]. He did not play for the rest of the regular season. On December 30, the day after Denver's 34-14 victory over Oakland, head coach [[John Fox (American football)|John Fox]] announced that Welker was cleared to play the Broncos divisional playoff against the [[San Diego Chargers]] on January 12, 2014. He caught a touchdown in the 24–17 victory in the Divisional Round.{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/201401120den.htm |title=Divisional Round - San Diego Chargers at Denver Broncos - January 12th, 2014 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-03-15}} On January 19, Welker earned his third AFC Championship win and Super Bowl appearance after he helped the Broncos defeat his former team, [[New England Patriots]], 26-16, but failed to get his first Super Bowl ring. The Broncos lost to the Seattle Seahawks, 43-8 in [[Super Bowl XLVIII]], being the third Super Bowl loss of Welker's career. He had 8 catches for 84 yards in the loss.{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/201402020den.htm |title=Super Bowl XLVIII - Seattle Seahawks vs. Denver Broncos - February 2nd, 2014 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2017-11-03}} ====2014 season==== {{See also|2014 Denver Broncos season}} During the third preseason game on August 23, Welker was diagnosed with a concussion after a hit by [[Houston Texans]] safety [[D.J. Swearinger]], his third in 10 months.{{cite web | url=http://www.cbssports.com/nfl/eye-on-football/24677837/broncos-wr-wes-welker-diagnosed-with-third-concussion-in-10-months | title=Broncos WR Wes Welker diagnosed with third concussion in 10 months | publisher=CBSSports.com | work=cbssports.com | date=August 24, 2014 | accessdate=September 2, 2014 | author=Breech, John}} On September 2, the NFL suspended Welker for the first four games of the [[2014 NFL season]] for violating the league's performance-enhancing drug policy after he failed a drug test due to [[amphetamines]].{{cite web | url=http://www.cbssports.com/nfl/eye-on-football/24692023/report-broncos-wr-wes-welker-suspended-four-games | title=Broncos WR Wes Welker suspended four games for violating drug policy | publisher=CBSSports.com | work=cbssports.com | date=September 2, 2014 | accessdate=September 2, 2014 | author=Breech, John}} On September 12, Welker's suspension was lifted due to the NFL's new drug policy. Welker made his season debut in week 3. He had 6 catches for 60 yards in an overtime loss to the [[Seattle Seahawks]].{{cite web|url=http://www.nfl.com/news/story/0ap3000000393562/article/nflpa-approves-new-drug-policy-includes-hgh-testing|title=NFLPA approves new drug policy; HGH testing included|publisher=}} In a Week 7 game against the [[Arizona Cardinals]] on October 5, Welker passed [[Rod Smith (wide receiver)|Rod Smith]] for the most receptions by an undrafted player in NFL history. In a game against the [[San Francisco 49ers]], Welker caught his first touchdown of the season and it was [[Peyton Manning]]'s 508th career touchdown pass, which tied [[Brett Favre]] for the most all-time.{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/201410190den.htm |title=San Francisco 49ers at Denver Broncos - October 19th, 2014 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-03-15}} Overall, he finished the 2014 season with 49 receptions for 464 yards and two touchdowns.{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/players/W/WelkWe00/gamelog/2014/ |title=Wes Welker 2014 Game Log |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-03-15}} ===St. Louis Rams=== {{See also|2015 St. Louis Rams season}} On November 9, 2015, the [[St. Louis Rams]] signed Welker to a one-year, $1.8 million contract including incentives.{{cite web | url=http://www.nfl.com/news/story/0ap3000000576758/article/wes-welker-signs-with-st-louis-rams | title=Wes Welker signs with St. Louis Rams | publisher=nfl.com | date=November 9, 2015 | accessdate=November 9, 2015}} He appeared in eight games, but started none, and had 13 receptions for 102 yards for the Rams in the 2015 season.{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/players/W/WelkWe00/gamelog/2015/ |title=Wes Welker 2015 Game Log |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-03-15}} The 2015 season would be Welker's last in the NFL as a player. ===Career statistics=== ====Regular season==== {| class=wikitable style="text-align:center;" ! rowspan="2"| Year ! rowspan="2"| Team ! colspan="2"| Games ! colspan="5"| Receiving ! colspan="5"| Rushing ! colspan="2"| Fumbles |- !
