15.0 || 0 |} ===NFL records=== * Most seasons with 105+ receptions: 5 * Most seasons with 110+ receptions: 5 * Most seasons with 115+ receptions: 3 * Most seasons with 120+ receptions: 2 (tied with [[Cris Carter]] and [[Antonio Brown]]) * Most consecutive seasons with 110 receptions: 3 (tied with [[Antonio Brown]]) * Most games with 12+ receptions: 9 * Most games with 13+ receptions: 5 * Most games with 15+ receptions: 2 (tied with [[Jason Witten]], [[Brandon Marshall]], and [[Antonio Brown]]) * Most games with 10+ receptions in a season: 7 (tied with [[Andre Johnson]]) * Fastest receiver to have 500 catches with one team ([[New England Patriots]]) (70 games) * Longest touchdown reception: 99 (2011 vs [[Miami Dolphins]]) (tied with 12 others) * Most receptions of any undrafted free agent in NFL history: 903 * Most career punt returns without a touchdown: 264 * Most career punt return yards without a touchdown: 2,584 ===Dolphins franchise records=== * Most career kick return yards: 3,756{{cite web | title = Miami Dolphins Franchise Encyclopedia | work = sports-reference.com | url = https://www.pro-football-reference.com/teams/mia/ | accessdate = 21 August 2012 }} * Most career combined Kick and Punt return yards (4,988) * Most all-purpose yards in a single season: 2,208 (2005) * Most punt return yards in a single season: 464 (2004) ===Patriots franchise records=== * Most career receptions: 672 * Most receptions in a single season: 123 (2009){{cite web | title = New England Patriots Franchise Encyclopedia | work = pro-football-reference.com | url = https://www.pro-football-reference.com/teams/nwe/ | accessdate = 21 August 2012 }} * Most receiving yards in a single season: 1,569 (2011) * Most seasons with 100 receptions or more: 5 * Best receiving yards per game average (season): 98.1 (2011) ==Professional coaching career== On January 30, 2017, Welker acquired his first coaching job after the [[Houston Texans]] hired him to be an offensive and special teams assistant coach.{{cite web|work=NFL.com|url=http://www.nfl.com/news/story/0ap3000000780924/article/texans-hire-wes-welker-as-coaching-assistant|title=Texans hire Wes Welker as coaching assistant|first= Max|last=Meyer|date=January 30, 2017|accessdate=January 31, 2017}} ==Personal life== Welker was born in [[Oklahoma City, Oklahoma]], and is a [[Christianity|Christian]].{{cite web|title=Wes Welker|url=http://www.thegoal.com/players/football/welker_wess/welker_wess.html|website=The Goal}} Welker is of partial [[Cherokee]] descent. He is a citizen of the [[Cherokee Nation of Oklahoma|Cherokee Nation]], and has a grandmother who lives on tribal lands in [[Sequoyah County, Oklahoma|Sequoyah County]], Oklahoma.{{cite web|last1=Hubbard|first1=Julie|title=Cherokee Nation supports new Jack Brown Center; honors citizens|url=http://www.cherokee.org/News/Stories/33323.aspx|website=Cherokee Nation of Oklahoma|accessdate=28 August 2016|ref=16 January 2013}} While attending [[Texas Tech University]], Welker was a Texas Epsilon chapter member of the [[Phi Delta Theta]] fraternity.{{cite web|url=http://www.phideltatheta.org/index.php?Itemid=129&id=24&option=com_content&task=view|title=Phi Delta Theta Athletics|work=[[Phi Delta Theta]]|accessdate=2010-01-11}} Welker graduated from Texas Tech University in 2003 with a [[Bachelor of Business Administration]] degree in [[Management]] from the [[Rawls College of Business]].{{cite web|url=https://issuu.com/tturawlscollege/docs/prospective_students_rawls_college|title=Prospective Students Viewbook|publisher=}} In 2007, Welker established the 83 Foundation (after his NFL uniform number). The foundation, renamed the Wes Welker Foundation in December 2009, states its goal is "to influence at-risk youth, by encouraging their full potential through athletics and positive role models". Its work primarily benefits schools and other organizations in Welker's hometown of Oklahoma City. In 2012, Welker married former swimsuit model Anna Burns.{{cite web|url=http://bleacherreport.com/articles/1940602-anna-burns-welker-wes-welkers-wife-a-potential-super-bowl-xlviii-hot-topic|title=Anna Burns Welker: Wes Welker's Wife a Potential Super Bowl XLVIII Hot Topic|first=Dan|last=Carson|publisher=}} They have three children.{{Cite news|url=https://nypost.com/2017/07/20/wes-welkers-post-football-life-crisis/|title=Wes Welker’s post-football life crisis|date=2017-07-20|work=New York Post|access-date=2018-05-13|language=en-US}} Welker owns a chestnut colored gelding racehorse called Undrafted, trained by [[Wesley A. Ward|Wesley Ward]]. In 2014, Undrafted notched his first win in the Grade 3 Jaipur Invitational Stakes at Belmont.{{cite web|title=Jaipur Invitational S. (gr. III) - Race 4 at Belmont Park on June 7, 2014|url=http://www.bloodhorse.com/horse-racing/race/USA/BEL/2014/6/7/4/jaipur-invitational-s-gr-iii|website=Blood-Horse|accessdate=17 September 2014}} Undrafted also won the Group 1 2015 [[Diamond Jubilee Stakes]] at [[Ascot Racecourse]]. ==References== {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}} ==External links== {{Commons category}} {{Footballstats |nfl=WEK219433 |cfl= |afl= |espn=5941 |cbs=493735 |yahoo=7027 |fox= |si=7027 |pfr=W/WelkWe00 |rotoworld=}} *[http://www.weswelker.com Official website] *[http://www.texastech.com/sports/m-footbl/mtt/welker_wes00.html Texas Tech biography] *[http://www.denverbroncos.com/team/roster/Wes-Welker/b622ff07-2e34-4bec-8e8b-610b9e0965e4 Denver Broncos biography] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20121007034028/http://www.patriots.com/team/roster/wes-welker/1bfbe111-c834-4e34-9ce5-78929ff09d1d/ New England Patriots biography] {{Mosi Tatupu Award}} {{Patriots2000s}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Welker, Wes}} [[Category:1981 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Sportspeople from Oklahoma City]] [[Category:Players of American football from Oklahoma]] [[Category:American football wide receivers]] [[Category:American football return specialists]] [[Category:Texas Tech Red Raiders football players]] [[Category:Rawls College of Business alumni]] [[Category:San Diego Chargers players]] [[Category:Miami Dolphins players]] [[Category:New England Patriots players]] [[Category:Denver Broncos players]] [[Category:St. Louis Rams players]] [[Category:American Conference Pro Bowl players]] [[Category:American sportspeople in doping cases]] [[Category:Native American sportspeople]] [[Category:American people of Native American descent]] [[Category:Cherokee people]] [[Category:Houston Texans coaches]]

revision.text:
{{multiple issues| {{primary sources|date=April 2013}} {{more citations needed|date=May 2010}} }} {{Infobox comics character<!--This box is part of Wikipedia:WikiProject Comics. See that article for details--> |image= Zeus Dc Comics.png |caption=Zeus as he appears in [[The New 52]] continuity |character_name=Zeus |publisher=[[DC Comics]] |debut=''[[Superman]]'' #28 (May 1944) |creators=[[George Pérez]] |alter_ego =Zeus |species = <!-- optional --> |homeworld =[[Mount Olympus]] |alliances=[[Olympian Gods (DC Comics)|Olympian Gods]] |partners = <!-- optional --> |aliases =[[Jupiter (mythology)|Jupiter]], Jove |supports =<!--optional--> |powers=Deity, vast supernatural abilities including [[Magic (paranormal)|magic]], size-changing, [[shapeshifting]], cloning, energy manipulation, [[immortality]], and command of storms and lightning, superspeed, superstrength. |}} '''Zeus''' is a [[fictional deity]] in the [[DC Comics]] [[DC Universe|universe]], an interpretation of [[Zeus]] from [[Greek mythology]]. His appearances are most significant in stories of [[Wonder Woman]] (Princess Diana). With the 2011 relaunch of DC Comics dubbed [[The New 52]], Zeus has received a prominent role in the Wonder Woman mythos, as he is now the biological father of Wonder Woman through [[Hippolyta (DC Comics)|Hippolyta]].
==Fictional character biography== Zeus' origins and early history mostly conform to the way they are presented in classical mythology. He is a child of the [[Titan (mythology)|Titans]] [[Cronus]] and [[Rhea (mythology)|Rhea]] and leader of the twelve [[Olympian Gods (DC Comics)|Olympian Gods]]. During a war between the Titans and Olympians, Zeus slays his father and assumes his place as King of the Gods, ruling from [[Mount Olympus]] with his sister-wife [[Hera (DC Comics)|Hera]]. He is the father of numerous gods and heroes, the most famous being [[Hercules (DC Comics)|Hercules]].
In the DC Universe, the machinations of the alien god [[Darkseid]] when he spreads tales of the Roman Gods cause the Olympians to split into multiple aspects, with the [[Roman mythology|Roman]] gods existing for a time as separate entities. Zeus' counterpart [[Jupiter (mythology)|Jupiter]] rules his own Olympus in a separate dimension following this. The two pantheons are merged into single entities again centuries later.
In present day, Zeus has been a benefactor of the [[Amazons (DC Comics)|Amazons]], the last remaining people that still worship the Olympians. However, his patriarchal attitudes, disregard for mortals, and unreasonable demands have sometimes led to conflict with his followers, particularly their champion Wonder Woman.
After Wonder Woman's defeat of [[Ares (DC Comics)|Ares]], which caused the latter to go into self-exile, Zeus becomes interested in Diana and wants her [[virginity]], offering to make her a goddess. Diana becomes the first woman ever to refuse his advances while professing love for him as god and father. Enraged at being rejected, Zeus threatens her, but is summoned back to Olympus by [[Hera]] at the urging at the Goddesses who created the Amazons and are incensed themselves at Zeus trying to make Themyscira his personal brothel. As punishment, Zeus demands that Diana undertake the Challenge of the Gods, on which she defeats the evils that have been trapped under [[Themyscira (DC Comics)|Paradise Island]], including a [[Hecatonchires|Hecatonshire]] and the [[Lernaean Hydra]]. She frees Heracles, who had been turned to stone and was supporting the Island.<ref>''Wonder Woman'' (vol. 2) #7-16</ref>
During a [[War of the Gods (comics)|War of the Gods]], Zeus leads the Olympians in a conflict with their Roman counterparts and other deities, until mortal heroes intervene to end the war. After Darkseid destroys the glory of [[Mount Olympus|Olympus]],<ref>''[[Action Comics]]'' #600</ref> Zeus convinces the other gods to abandon both it and Earth, and only [[Hermes (DC Comics)|Hermes]] refuses. The gods later return to Olympus but have occasionally been forced to defend or relocate it.
As in classical myth, Zeus frequently cheats on his wife Hera and couples with mortals to produce [[demi-god]] offspring. Zeus has been revealed as the father of [[Wonder Girl (Cassie Sandsmark)]] and shares a complicated relationship with his daughter, who resents his absence from most of her life.
Zeus is briefly deposed as ruler of Olympus during a coup staged by his daughter [[Athena (DC Comics)|Athena]] with help from Ares. In the wake of this conflict, Athena becomes Queen of the Gods and Ares is appointed Lord of the [[Greek Underworld|Underworld]]. Shortly after this, the gods enter their second exile, following the Amazons into another dimension after the events of the [[Infinite Crisis]]. Their return to the Earth-realm is brought about by Darkseid, who captures the Olympians and tampers with their memories, seeking the secrets of their power. In ''[[Countdown to Final Crisis]]'' Darkseid's [[New Gods]] pose as Olympians and manipulate their followers. Once freed from Darkseid, the old Olympian order is restored. Athena seemingly perishes from her sustained injuries and Zeus once again becomes King of the Gods, giving Mary Marvel her powers back after she frees the Gods from a chamber on Apokolips.
Zeus' manipulations of his followers finally come to a head with the creation of the [[Gargareans]], a race of warriors intended as male counterparts of the Amazons. Zeus murders the [[Hawaii]]an god [[Kāne Milohai]], a patron of Wonder Woman, and uses his heart to resurrect [[Olympian (comics)#Achilles Warkiller|Achilles Warkiller]], whom he appoints as leader of the Gargareans. Zeus also instates Achilles as the new ruler of [[Themyscira (DC Comics)|Themyscira]]. When Wonder Woman learns of this and of the murder of Kāne, she becomes enraged and physically assaults Zeus. This blasphemy shocks her mother [[Hippolyta (DC Comics)|Hippolyta]] and leads Diana to enter self-exile, forsaking her former
In September 2011, [[The New 52]] rebooted DC's continuity. In this new timeline, Wonder Woman's origin is revised, with her now being the biological daughter of Zeus. Zeus and Hippolyta engaged in combat, and their fight ended with the couple having sex, and thus Diana was conceived. This encounter was hidden from Diana, who was raised to believe that she was born out of clay, in order to protect Diana from Hera (Zeus' wife).<ref>''Wonder Woman'' Vol. 4 #3</ref> Lennox (another illegitimate offspring of Zeus) commented that Zeus has been "scarpered off the immortal coil", hinting that he has apparently died.<ref>''Wonder Woman'' Vol. 4 #5</ref> It is revealed that Zeus was reborn as a baby by his daughter [[Athena]] (much as Zeus had given birth to her from his head) who had been plunged into the fictitious personality and matching body of a woman named [[Zola (DC Comics)|Zola]] who believed Zeke to be her youngest son by Zeus. Fulfilling the prophecy involving Zeus's last born son, Zeke is revealed to be the king of the gods himself, and the spell on Athena ends. Wonder Woman pleads with Athena, however, to vacate this form she has created so Wonder Woman can keep her friend Zola and mother to the new baby Zeus, who could be a better king of the gods with Zola as the mother he never really had before in his life.<ref>''Wonder Woman'' Vol. 4 #35</ref>
==Powers and abilities== Depending on the writer, Zeus' powers require either direct or indirect worship to sustain them. Without this worship his powers may fade over time allowing other gods to equal or surpass him.
In most stories, Zeus is one of or the most powerful Olympian god. He has vast supernatural powers with a focus on weather control, but can accomplish nearly anything including shapeshifting, resurrecting the dead, and creating new life.
==In other media== ===Television=== * In the long-running animated series ''[[Super Friends]]'', Wonder Woman says either "Great Zeus" or "Great Hera" as an interjection when she and other superheroes are in difficult situations. * Zeus appears in the ''[[Challenge of the Super Friends]]'' episode "Battle of the Gods", voiced by [[Bob Holt (actor)|Bob Holt]]. When Hera gets jealously angered at Aphrodite's praise for the Super Friends, she and Aphrodite bicker over the matter. Outraged by such a disturbance, Zeus decides to settle this dispute by having the Super Friends partake in different trials where Hera hopes that none of them will succeed in. The trials that Zeus puts the Super Friends through involve having [[Superman]] find and defeat the [[Minotaur]], having [[Batman]] and [[Dick Grayson|Robin]] solve the Riddle of the [[Sphinx]], having Wonder Woman retrieve the necklace of [[Medusa (DC Comics)|Medusa]], and having [[Aquaman]] retrieve the [[Golden Fleece]].
===Film=== ====[[DC Extended Universe]]==== {{main|DC Extended Universe}} ''[[Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice]]''{{'}}s producer [[Charles Roven]] confirmed that [[Wonder Woman|Diana Prince / Wonder Woman]], portrayed by [[Gal Gadot]], is the biological daughter of Zeus, confirming his existence in the film universe.
* Zeus is referenced in ''[[Wonder Woman (2017 film)|Wonder Woman]]'' (2017). Zeus and other [[Olympian Gods|Olympians]] are depicted through [[Computer-generated imagery|CGI]] effects, showing the images of the storybook that Queen [[Hippolyta (DC Comics)|Hippolyta]] reads to a young Diana. Queen Hippolyta explains to Diana Prince that Zeus is the leader of the Olympian Gods, and that he created the Amazons to protect and help humankind. Over time, his son [[Ares (DC Comics)|Ares]] revolted, corrupted men and killed most of the Olympians in battle. Zeus defeated Ares and cast him off of Mount Olympus while getting wounded in the process. After the imprisonment of the Amazonian women by the wicked men of the Earth, Zeus creates [[Themyscira (DC Comics)|Themyscira]] to protect them, creating a cloaking effect to hide the island from the world. In his dying breath, Zeus leaves his Amazon warriors with the care of his and Hippolyta's daughter Diana and gives them a gift in the form of an artifact, the "Godkiller" sword. Later, it is revealed that Diana herself is the "Godkiller" as only a god can kill another god. * Zeus appears in the film ''[[Justice League (2017 film)|Justice League]]'' (2017), portrayed by Sergi Constance.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://collider.com/justice-league-what-we-know-so-far/ |title=‘Justice League’: Over 60 Things to Know About the ‘Batman v Superman’ Follow-Up |last=Weintraub |first=Steve |date=June 21, 2016 |website=Collider.com |publisher= |access-date=July 5, 2016}}</ref> He was seen during a flashback scene to ancient Earth. In ancient times as explained by Diana, the united armies of the Olympians, [[Atlantis (DC Comics)|Atlantean]]s, [[Amazons (DC Comics)|Amazons]], humans, and the [[Green Lantern Corps]] worked together to defeat [[Steppenwolf (comics)|Steppenwolf]], ending his previous invasion. Zeus was present during the battle among other Olympian Old Gods and used a lightning bolt to separate the three mother boxes to prevent them from fusing into each other. After the battle, the forces unite in protecting the Mother Boxes. Two are protected in Atlantis and Themyscira, respectively while the third is buried by the humans with the aid of the Olympians so as to prevent their destructive power from ever threatening Earth again.
====Animation==== * Zeus appears in the animated film ''[[Wonder Woman (2009 film)|Wonder Woman]]'' voiced by [[David McCallum]]. He and Hera appeared to prevent Hippolyta from killing Ares during a fight between the Amazons and the Armies of Ares.
===Video games=== * Zeus appears in ''[[DC Universe Online]]''. He appears in "Amazon Fury Part III" where Ares and Circe make plans of deposing Zeus.
==References== <references/>
